=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Makes a neat game for *certain* situations and falls short the rest of the time; I want to negotiate, but I'm dealing with people who have difficulty lying or obfuscating their desires. Another is if I have sufficient players as I think this is best around 5 (enough to create an unpleasant situation, but not enough so you get stuck somewhere). If you can get players who are all aggressive in their negotiations or manipulative in terms of markets/incentives, then the game is a big 8. When you have a group who are more about manipulating each other to their benefit and less about just optimizing their own fields, the game *really* shines. The problem is that to make that happen is once in a blue moon or at least erratically infrequent. Some neat calculations in terms of card counting and the three reshuffles in that you'll see some information, but not all of what's come up and is being held. The "you can't rearrange your hand" is both the most infuriating aspect of the game, and the one that drives it (and in particular, the negotiation phase) forward; suddenly giving away cards or doing lopsided trades make sense if it moves cards out of your hand. Combining that with the initial planting allows you to manipulate and incentivize transactions. I rarely turn down a game if it looks like there are a bunch of folks, but I can't think of a time when I've ever suggested it. Under perfect conditions, an 8, more likely to be a strong 6.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Set collection and trading game with an odd but fun theme.

Gameplay is simple: plant, trade, and pick up, with the goal of getting the most money at the game's end.  Along the way, there are tons of opportunities for trading/negotiation.  Fixed order of cards in hand is what drives alot of the trading, and is something that new players have to be mindful of. 

This is a very light, but very good gateway game (filler material) that works very well with 3-5 players.  Everyone that I've introduced it to loves it, with many rushing out to get their own copies.  An excellent way to introduce one of the greatest concepts in Euro gaming: having something to to (i.e.: trade) when it's not your turn.

Most games end up being extremely close so even when you lose, you don't feel bad.  Definitely a wife-friendly game as well.

Own the following expansions: [boardgame=1494]Bohnanza Erweiterungs-Set[/boardgame], [boardgame=4377]Ladybohn[/boardgame], [boardgame=8174]Dschingis Bohn[/boardgame], [boardgame=2571]Mutabohn[/boardgame], [boardgame=59416]Bohnedikt[/boardgame], [boardgame=13474]Telebohn[/boardgame], [boardgame=86012]Mutterbohnchen[/boardgame], [boardgame=26946]Manche Mogen's Heiss Ladybohn[/boardgame], [boardgame=31419]Bohnroschen[/boardgame], [boardgame=980]Al Cabohne[/boardgame], [boardgame=453]La Isla Bohnita[/boardgame], [boardgame=103186]Bohn Camillo[/boardgame], [boardgame=12677]High Bohn Plus[/boardgame], [boardgame=6264]Bohnaparte[/boardgame], the [boardgame=35428]Spiderbeans[/boardgame], and the [boardgame=189272]Bean Market Advent Calendar[/boardgame] promo tile.

Only two plays though and I was unaccustomed to various game mechanics beyond wargaming, Settlers of Catan and Carcassonne in 2007. Nearly five years later this game was great fun and is easy to appreciate. In 2007, I had rated the game a 6. What fun to upgrade a number significantly higher.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.05
Excellent quick and easy game with the right crowd.  A great concept where cards in hand are required to be "planted" in order, thus incentivizing trades to remove unwanted cards (or wanted cards in the wrong position) from one's hand--but suffers from the same problem as all trade-dependent games:  less fun with people who will only strike a deal that is heavily weighted in their favor or people who will give the farm away on charity.  This latter point particularly manifests itself in couples play.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I played this game just once, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

I enjoyed Bohnanza far more that I though I would. The reason might be that this game never caught my eye because of it artwork... I simply HATE IT! I cannot stand how ugly this game looks. Yet, when I tried it, it was a very enjoyable experience.

While a couple of mechanisms are a bit counterintuitive at first, Bohnanza packs a decent amount of game-play for such a small product. I especially enjoy the fact that there's a healthy dose of interaction. You cannot attack the players at the table, but the possibility of trading cards with them keeps you engaged... even if it's not your turn and even if you're playing with a lot of people.

So... while it's not a game I would buy for myself, it's definitively one I would play again. It's simple, it's fast, it's fun and it plays a crowd. If only it wasn't so ugly...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
In this game, I realize I'm a loud-mouthed gamer. I constantly want to maximize my profits and will gain Analysis Paralysis with a "hmm haww" when the stars don't align. This delay is worse in a negotiation game like this or Catan; I spend an inordinate amount of time trying to convince people to trade with me. Luckily, it usually works out because people just want to have fun and may be less invested in the outcome of the game. Note that in social deduction games, I am usually very suspicious because people can not guess what I'm thinking, even when I try to be explicit.
 Con: I think Bohnanza lasts longer than it should

RATING: 7
Here's the deal with this game, it's great. The mathematics of it are extremely interesting. It can handle bigger groups extremely well. This is the game that I pull out when my family wants to play something during the holidays. It's hard to find short and fun games that handle large groups of people, but everyone I've introduced this to has loved it.

The secret is that this game can be knocked out in an hour or so, but usually it lasts longer. Why? Well, the nature of this game is trading and negotiation. This is the game that you bring out when you want to get people talking face to face. It's especially good with some drinks too because people are able to lighten up and get into the wheeling and dealing of this game.

RATING: 6.9
Very simple, but fun game.  Probably the most fun "simple" card game I have played.  You lay cards down into stacks of the same type, and pick them up for points.  One unique thing about the game is that you have to play the cards in your hand in the order they were handed to you.  The only way to get past this is by trading cards to other players.  It is pretty fun trying to get the cards in the right order, and trying to make beneficial trades with everyone else in order to accomplish a better bean field for yourself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Set collection game with a wonderful mechanic that forces trades.  It's a bit like trading resources in Catan except those shy players are forced to make deals at least a few times a turn.  I think 5-6 players might be the sweet spot, but there isn't all that much down time if you play with larger groups.  This has potential to be one of my all-time favorites.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2-7(5)

This is one that resonates with a lot of players, and it can play a big group. All good things. It's easy to miss or confuse some of the rules. First that you HAVE to plant any of the revealed cards that you don't ditch and second that you HAVE to harvest a multibean field before a single bean one. After that, who knows what else we'll get wrong? The rationale for the rules makes sense, but it reduces the simplicity a bit.

There's a good bit of interesting planning involved in that you need to settle your hand before your turn comes back around, and too often people are too hesitant to trade unless it's their turn. The point of the game is to trade goods! A lot! It's fun and light to match the theme.

Only issues are that hand sizes seem to generally go down and small hands stifle trading and going through the deck three times sometimes feels a bit long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
2-7 players. Keep 2018.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
Plant bean cards onto the table in your fields, but do so in hand order (no shuffling or re-ordering!). Wheel and deal with your opponents so that you can trade their beans into your fields and sell them off to make big profits. Beans which are more plentiful are worth less while scare beans are worth more. You play through the draw deck a few times, with scored beans exiting the game permanently, then the game is over. Low rules complexity brings out a very powerful player meta which drives the game. 

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
I've never played a game that takes place so much more above the table than on it, in terms of interaction. This game brings out your inner snake oil salesman and really encourages sharp dealing with the other players. "Look, I know that trading you my two wax beans is not the same value as your single soy bean, but you're going to be forced to plant that soy bean against your wishes next turn, and that guy over there wants a one-for-one deal on wax to soy! That's nuts. He's taking you for a ride. If you want, I'll throw in a bean of my choosing next turn to sweeten the deal."

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
This game doesn't necessarily fall apart with purely analytical players, but if the game is played too coldly, the spirit (and interesting interactions) can dissipate quickly. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I honestly don't see what all the fuss is about with this game.  I find bean and fart joke humour, pointless and infantile, so none of that struck a chord with me.  Tried a two-player game, but it just didn't gel.  Being a card player, I found it very difficult to not reorder my hand.  Traded away

RATING: 7
This is a fun, chaotic game depending on the personalities of the players. Your turn involves proposing card trades with other players until you decide you don't want to trade anymore (or until the other players get fed up and plead with you to stop trying to trade)... which can drive me nuts when playing with my good-natured, roudy family. But, in all honesty, it's a good time. Just don't play this if you have a headache already. I complain and whine every time someone in my family suggests playing it. But, in reality, it's a great memory-maker and can be a blast. The rules and game-play are much different for just 2-players and not as fun. I think it's best with at least 4 players.

RATING: 8.5
I bought this game as a bit of a punt as I was looking for a game that was easily accessible for a variety of personalities and could handle a decent number of players.

I have introduced this to loads of my friends and everyone has loved it! Even though I have a number of other more expensive and more sophisticated games, this is the one my friends seem most keen on playing!

The game is simple to grasp (once you've read over the rules), and that makes it easy for people to engage with. At the same time, for people like myself that like a bit of strategy in a game rather than relying on luck, there is enough opportunity for that to keep me engaged whilst also engaging people that would run a mile from a heavy strategy game!

RATING: 4.5
Bohnanza was an endlessly entertaining Sunday brunch staple for my group of friends, back when it first came out. It brought us many hours of delightful bean-planting-and-harvesting. Ah, nostalgia... 

I still enjoy the artwork and the puns (though admittedly, the game is "punnier" in German). However, now that I'm familiar with more complex games, I find Bohnanza a bit too simple for my taste. I'd consider it a great entry choice for people who like to think and plan ahead a little during a game. 

I probably would have given this an 8 or 9 a few years ago. But I'm giving it a 4.5, because I wouldn't want to play it again.

RATING: 9
Excellent resource planning and trading game that's a blast every time I've played it. You make trades with other players to try and plant as many of the same types of bean in your two fields as possible, before selling them off for gold. A lot more fun than it sounds, and the theme is actually quite engaging.

A bit of an acquired taste, but definitely worth a go.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Thought this is still one of the best game where is a quite a bit of player interaction since you need to trade or plant beans that are revealed in the second step. Very neat game with very little down time since you need to see what others are planting and what is available for donation.

Been a while since we last played the game so need quick refreshers so going to add the quick rules,

1. 3rd field cost 3 gold.
2. 1st action is to plant 1st bean and 2nd bean (optional).
3. 2nd action is to draw TWO cards and trade/donate them, failure to do so requires the current player to plant them.
4. 3rd action is to draw 3 cards and add to the back of the deck.

Was a good game and have to remember that this caters to up to 7 players!

[b][url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1134055/part-2014-challenge-play-10-games-case-bohnanza-10]Bohnanza Session Report for 2014 10x10 Challenge[/url][/b]

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A superior game that's lots of fun. We play it often.

We learned it as a 2-player and still play that version a lot. Some players don't like this "Bean Duel", but almost all of our games are close, with the winner having 1 or 2 coins more which makes for an interesting experience. If you like games like this, you'll like the 2-player version.

We also like it with more than 2. That version has lots of player interaction which is enjoyable. The bartering and trading can be very competitive.

Bohnanza is really two very different games in one, and both are fun! Highly recommended.

Add the Buildings variant from High Bohn Plus for a game with more decisions. 

NOTE: Check out my player aid "Two Player Turn Order" in the the Bohnanza FILES section.

RATING: 8

Choosing when to start new fields or hang on for the big score, the interaction of trading cards, and the great card art are all bonuses in my book.  I've owned this for nearly two years now, and only gotten to play 3-4 times total.  No sense picking up the expansions if no one will play the base game with me.  [Market price]

RATING: 8
Like it very much. It can be a little tricky getting used to not adjusting the order of your hand and negotiating with others to get your beans in the ground but it's well worth the effort. Fun! And it plays up to 8!

The down side is negotiating with people who don't want to negotiate simply for the sake of making your life difficult. Those types of people can and will tank an otherwise enjoyable experience just to spite you.

RATING: 8.7

RATING: 7.5
This game is all kinds of fun.  I love all the bartering and bickering that this game can spawn.  This is another game where everyone I know whose played it has really enjoyed it.  Some even run out and buy it very shortly after their first time playing it.  I'd say that's the mark of a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 5th Place 1997[/SIZE][/COLOR]

[i]Posted: 2/12/06, Rated: 7[/i]

[i]Bohnanza[/i] is a fun little game, that takes a different view on set-collection, and introduces a new mechanic to card games with which I have not yet played.

You can only collect two sets at a time (later in the game, you have the opportunity to expand this number to three).  At the beginning of your turn, you [i]must[/i] plant the first card in your hand, which means you may have to harvest a bean "field" in order to make room, often before you would have liked to do so.  This limiting mechanic is a fun addition that creates tough decisions: do I take the easy, one coin from a field now?  Or do I hold on to those beans, hoping they will earn more later, and instead harvest my second field which doesn't yet have enough beans to earn anything?

The "first card in your hand" is easy to determine because you must play your cards in the order in which you drew them.  You may not adjust the order of the cards in your hand.  This is a new idea, and I really like it.  This card order often influences your play in the current turn: you could plant two beans of the same type now, or you could hold on to that second one because you think you will be able to play it as the first card in your next turn.  Of course, you may end up trading for other beans before the start of your next turn, have to harvest that very bean field, and then that first card is an albatross around your neck.

Trading and haggling are also a vital part of [i]Bohnanza,[/i] and in my opinion that kind of interactivity always enhances a game.  [i]Bohnanza[/i] plays well from two to four players.  The box says it goes up to seven, but I haven't tried any more than four yet.  The two player variant is different enough to allow for longer-range planning, which I enjoy.  Lastly, the whimsical artwork on the cards has been well-received by my two sons, ages seven and five, who enjoy playing as well.  A solid, lightweight game for the family!

[i]Updated: 1/4/08, Rated: 7[/i]

Re-asserting my original rating of "7."  This game is still a lot of fun.  My sons are shrewder in their trades now, which makes the experience more interesting.  I'd bump it to an "8," but longevity alone is not enough to warrant the increase.

[i]Updated: 8/9/10, Rated: 8[/i]
{2P: 5, 3P: 7, 4P: 8, 5P: 9, 6P: ?, 7P: ?}

Have we really been playing this game for four years?  The answer is "yes."  Like a fine wine, [i]Bohnanza[/i] has gotten better with age.  Not my cards, unfortunately, and my wife tells me that she will refuse to play this game if I sleeve it!

I think we've finally reached a level of expertise where the game has fully opened up.  Ironically, it is still usually in your best interest to trade away beans your opponents need, if only to keep your own hand optimized.  

Now we realize the importance of being in markets where other players aren't competing.  We also track the number of each particular type of bean available after it has been harvested; no one wants a Garden Bean or a Red Bean if the others have already been sold.  Lastly, keeping track of [i]when[/i] cards are placed in the discard pile is an important consideration, especially before the last trip through the deck.  All of these considerations merge beautifully, and the 4P game is very enjoyable.

We had the chance to play the 5P game while my niece was staying with us.  It's even [i]better[/i].  Both of these realizations finally bump [i]Bohnanza[/i] up a point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Okay so I actually HAD to rate this game highly because my entire family absolutely LOVES it (they aren't hardcore board-gamers but do enjoy the occasional game of Catan or Dixit).  Anyway, it's by Uwe Rosenberg (the dude who made Agricola) and is a pretty lightweight card game.  The rules are easy to teach and there is constant player interaction with the ability to help/hurt other players.  I recommend this game because it is extremely versatile in that it works well with various player counts (it has specific changes based on number of characters that keep the game balanced) and it can be enjoyed by hardcore and casual gamers alike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For me, the more the merrier. Love this game. Great trading involved.

This game absolutely rocks with 5-7. There seems to be several people to trade with each round. You can even get people to give you beans for nothing. Seems pricey and unwise to dig 3rd bean field in 6-7 player game because there is always someone to trade with. To be good at this game you must try to deal with every person on every turn and corner a unique market. Be careful when trying to compete in bean market because there will be less to go around and more competition for trading.

The next time I play, I'm going to just repeatedly call out, like a stadium vendor or a carny, the kinds of beans I have to offer other players. If they need them they'll let me know. That should get me some deals.

RATING: 8
A very entertaining card game.  The rule keeping you from sorting your hand is so contrary to the rules in any other card game that it can be a challenge to remember, but it really makes the game work.  We usually play this game as a kind game where there is a lot of donations and fair trades, but it can be ratcheted up so that you are a bit more cut-throat

This was one of our first games and it has had a place in our collection for years.  We always pull this game out when we want some comfort gaming with our family.  And really that's the perfect audience for this game, you want to play with families and non-gamers.  The strategy isn't high, but the fun is.

RATING: 7.4
Easy card game with trading and tons of player interaction. This one is a winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great game of trading and negotiation.  Very simple and yet I feel like I am involved in it whether I win or not.  Every game of this we've ever played has finished very close.  It can lead to some conflict, but overall it's always a very fun, social game.

This game really requires the right group.  People willing to talk and trade and make deals will make this game great; others won't.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's a great bridging game between gamers and non-gamers PROVIDED your group plays fast enough not to let the trading drag.  If people dawdle too long on the negotiations, the game gets a little boring.

Strategy is thin.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of the first games I ever played, this bean planting card game is an evergreen that sees at least a play or two a year. Weelin' and dealin' is a must to get and plant the beans you need to and while sometimes someone lucks out and gets a lot of the rarer beans, being able to cash in on the common ones usually leads to success. 

This game is still one of my go-to's as a gateway game to people who come from card playing backgrounds.

RATING: 4
There was a time when Bohnanza was a fun game: then better games were discovered, all of them more exciting than Bohnanza, which thence fell quickly into a well deserved oblivion.

Its major issue is, it’s a filler by theme, look and gameplay but it takes way too much time to be a real filler: add to this its main rule - the one preventing players from reorganize the cards they have in their hands - and you will have enough of Bohnanza soon. [i](February 2012)[/i]

[b]Update[/b] - The mere thought of playing Bohnanza again makes me sick, hence during my Fall 2015 rating revise I lowered my rating from 5 to 4.

It may not be a 'great' game, but it's a very fun game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game will always be a classic in my mind.  If you approach it as an excercise in min/maxing your points, you'll probably be frustrated.  If you approach it as a negotiation game with some reasonable formatting to control the chaos of trading, it's a blast.  Distills the negotiation aspect of much longer complicated games into a simple core mechanic and plays fast.  Lots of little decisions to make, lots of moments of both relief and regret, and lots of room for creative solutions.  Fun, and that's what gaming is all about for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun fun fun.

RATING: 9
This game is a great game for the family, my daughters (12 and 13) cannot get enough of it.  In addition to the fun and time together, it also encourages interaction and cooperation to an extent.  Fast to play and set up.  Nice change of pace from heavier games.  
The design (pictures on the cards) are a big plus; bright colors with with a fun look!
I originally gave it an 8.5 only because I prefer heavier games, but changed it to a 9 because of the unique concept and interaction involved.
Everyone should have this game!

RATING: 8
(11 plays) This is a great game! I love its interactive trading phase, it has just the right length for what it offers and it rewards clever trading, albeit being somewhat luck dependent. I have been playing several games now with my usual group and we all like it a lot.

I have been playing two six player games, too, using the 'Bohnanza Expansion Set' and found that the game drags on then, but it is still fun.

All that said, it's a game which should be played light heartedly. Players who are prone to make the one optimal trade may severely bog down the game and take a lot of fun out of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Bohnanza shines for a few reasons...

1) It is light enough that it doesn't feel like work.

2) It has interesting decisions and tension

3) The presence of trading and the tension of fixed hand order means that you are engaged in the game on everyone else's turn (which is something most light traditional card games lack)

In Bohnanza, you can chat with people around the table and just have an overall relaxing yet engaging experience with your friends and family. This absolutely kills games like Uno and Phase 10. Once someone knows the rules, it doesn't feel that much harder. Yet it provides decisions, engagement, and it's not just blind luck!

The one downside of Bohnanza is it can be a little difficult to teach with non-gamers (the audience that this game shines with). If people give it a chance, they'll get it after once or twice around the table, but it's been a tough sell to even get people to try it in my experience
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

On Second play, opinion holds.  Artwork turns us off.  Rather play other card games.

I have no interest in playing it again since a) trading is one of my least favorite mechanics, and b) it felt like a light party game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A wonderful filler for almost any number of players (with the expansion.)

This game always has a very relaxed feeling to it, since it is often helpful to help someone else by trading or even gifting beans. So even while playing to win, it feels less competitive than other games.

An especially interesting aspect of the trading in this game is that if you play too tight and only make deals that are only beneficial to you or at least mutually beneficial, people might stop trading with you altogether out of spite. I really enjoy this kind of group-think, because it encourages everyone to play (moderately) nicely in order to win. The same can happen in other games with trading (e.g. Settlers of Catan), but in Bonanza, where trading is the core pf the game, it plays a more significant role.

[microbadge=48]

# of players: [bgcolor=#99FFFF] 3 [/bgcolor][bgcolor=#00CC00] 4 [b]5[/b][/bgcolor]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
By far the best game about bean-trading that I have ever had the pleasure of playing.  Beans are pretty cool.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game manages to be simultaneously fun and yet cleverly strategic in how you manage your beans. There's a good degree of social engineering in this game (in that, it reminds me of trading in Settlers or allying in Cosmic Encounter) in getting people to take beans from you when it may not be to their advantage. A certain sort of economics is involved, too: yes, a chili bean is worth more than a wax bean, but which means more to you and your bean fields? The most effective strategy I've found is to hold off buying a third field for as long as possible. Also, a Zen-like acceptance of your luck in drawing cards helps, too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Only played twice. Surprisingly deep for a simple trading game, I like the swapping/gifting and the fact you can only plant cards in order from your hand.

RATING: 7.6
This game is a fun bartering game. It's easy to grasp and a good game for non-board game people. The game seems to go fairly quickly and keeps people interested. It's also usually a close finish which keeps everyone happy. The only downside is that it can get emo when people feel like they are getting taken advantage of or when a newbie is trading too freely to the best talker(and the best talker is not you ;) ) Overall a great game. The fan edition is especially enjoyable as you get to look at the funky art while you are waiting for your turn.

PS- I don't care what the game says, their called cowboys NOT blue beans.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very light, very accessible card game. Far too long for what it is, but entertaining nonetheless. The strict hand-order mechanic is unusual and takes some getting used to, but is pretty fun once you embrace it. Because you can't change the order of cards in your hand, however, it's basically a pure negotiation game, which can be both random and frustrating, instead of a more traditional hand management game where you have more control. Not my favorite, but certainly different from other card games we own, and it's great for non-gamers, so that's a plus. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
For me, Bohnanza is the ultimate pure negotiation/trading game.  It plays quickly and you spend the whole time bargaining and begging, yelling and pleading.  It's wonderful.

This would be no find played quietly, as a eurogame, so you need a group of people who are willing to be vocal.  And you certainly have to be in the mood for politics.  When those conditions are met, Bohnanza is never far from my mind.

RATING: 9
Great fun, and very different from any other card game I've played.  Even my 5 and 8 year old enjoy it (we made a card holder for my 5 year old by cutting a slot in a foot-long 2x2 board).  It takes a couple of plays to get the rules down, but it is quite intuitive after that.  Love the pics on the cards too!

UPDATE:  Still going strong with this game after two years of fairly frequent family play.  Along with Frank's Zoo, this is our most beloved family game. It's got real staying power!

RATING: 8
Played once with three players. I did not have high expectations for this game, but wow, what a blast. The free-form trading is the key. By the end of the game (we only exhausted the deck once, due to the late hour), we had each drawn elaborate "contracts" with the opposing players: "If I take your two coffee beans, you promise to give me three cards that I want, over a maximum of two turns." Surprisingly, honest promises were more fun than broken promises, which introduced considerable rancor when they occurred and so were banned (by consensus).

UPDATE: Downgrading from 9 to 8 because our second play took way too long (2.5 hours for 5 players) and got a little bit repetitive. Must figure out how to speed things up.

UPDATE: Played with 3 people who know the game well, the game just blazes along. We actually played it twice in about an hour and a half -- and with the proper ending conditions too (exhausting the deck thrice)! Wonderful game.

RATING: 7
A pure trading/hand management game, made interesting in that you can never reorganize your hand.  So you'll need to do a lot of hardcore trading in order to get out of playing cards that you really don't want to play.  In fact, half the time you'll be willing to make some terrible trades just to get out of a card.

Great game to introduce people to the hobby!  All in all, I'd usually be willing to play this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
4/10/10: After one play, it's clear that Bohnanza is really not my sort of game.  The game is 90% negotiation and 10% hand-management.  While it is slightly less appalling than Killer Bunnies, it exists in roughly the same space.  

If all players were equally skilled in evaluating the relative value of the bean cards, the winner would be determined by a combination of luck-of-the-draw and kingmaking/bash-the-leader.  To make it resemble a strategy game, then, Bohnanza seems to require an exploitation of the new or weak players, often through cajoling or other meta-gaming.  This, I take no enjoyment from.  


2/6/11: With additional plays (largely because my game group loves it), I've actually come around a bit on Bohnanza.  It's not a game that I would recommend to others, and I'm not particularly eager to play it, but it's a more interesting game than most of the card-based filler that all-too-often hits the table with my group (Guillotine, for example).

RATING: 7
This one took me a while to warm up to but I now enjoy it quite a bit. It appears at first to be a rather bland, traditional playing card game but it is in fact an excellent negotiation game with a lot of depth and meaningful player interaction. However, even though it plays anywhere from 2-7 players, the more players you have the better and it really requires 3 at least to be worthwhile. It's also a great family game to play over the holidays.

RATING: 6

Some nifty trading rules make the trading and planting fun and tense--this is one of those games where, at least in the early phases, you can never quite do what you want to do. That's a good thing.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is my go-to recommendation for a good trading and negotiation game.

The best part of the game is the market fluctuations - sometimes someone will want to get rid of beans more than anyone else will want to take them. It makes the trading an interesting dynamic.

A couple rules to keep in mind:

- You can't change the order of the cards in your hand.
- You can't dig up a one-bean field, if you have fields with more than one bean.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There's a quantity versus quality tension here that I really appreciate. A player who focuses on getting the best deals will likely do worse than one who focuses on getting lots of deals, even if they come slightly behind on some of them. There is a point where this no longer holds, of course, but it is a fascinating point of tension.

The hand management of this game is one of the most brilliant mechanisms I've ever seen. It's what encourages people to not only want to get in deals, but also to give.

For best results, people should not be spending five minutes haggling over deals or trying to get people to make them. If you can't make a deal right away, just accept it and move on. If this game drags, it really drags.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This becomes less fun with each game I play.  I might be playing wrong but half of the cards that get flipped nobody wants.  Maybe if you have 5 or 6 people it would be okay.  But with 3 or 4 there just isn't enough competition for the cards to encourage enough trading.  I'm still giving it a five in the hopes that the game will improve if we add more players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic. Not being able to rearrange your hand really makes for some great tension. It's light enough that even nongamers can play and enjoy it, but it's even better when played with a really cutthroat group!

Update: This is one of the first games I bought when getting into the hobby, and honestly it's probably still my favorite trading game. Not being able to rearrange your hand makes for some real desperation, which leads to a level of ferocity with trades that isn't present in many other games in the genre. Like all negotiation games, it's really group-dependent but when it shines, it really shines bright.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What a funny little game this is! I never imagined it could actually be so much fun - I'm not sure WHY it is, but it is. I guess it's because of the elements of luck, tactics, good/funny artwork on the cards, auction and tough negotiation all combined in a good little card game which plays 2-7 players. I do prefer it with 4-5 - 3 and 6 are also okay, but 2 is not funny and 7 drags on and on. Actually, even with 4-5 players it might go on a little long depending on your game group, but that could basically be said about every game. I think it's a great and very unique game and many non-gamers seem to like it as they often request that we play it.

Additionally, there are multiple expansions for this game which can spice up the game if it turns out to be repetitive, but I like vanilla Bohnanza very much on its own!

My recommended number of players: 4, 5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
When I first read the rules I thought "Dude, where's the game?" Really, it doesn't sound like much at all when you read the rules. But then you play! Trading, trading, trading---"I'll take your wax if you take my stink." Can't change the order of your hand = brilliant design. 

Update January 09: Just taught and witnessed one of the most amazingly active and wild games of Bohnanza I've ever seen---WHAT A JOY! Maybe it isn't the tightest strategic exercise but people can throw themselves into the trading. Raised score just because of watching a game be so fun for new players. My students were cracking up and yelling and totally immersed in bean farming. BEAUTIFUL THING TO WITNESS!

Beans. Frigg'n awesome beans!

RATING: 5
*5* (3+ Plays)

I do think it would be better with 4-6 players because the trading among players will be better.  The game and theme are family friendly for game times, but I wouldn't want to play it otherwise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My criterion for rating games


http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/147053/item/2300390#item2300390


1) Sense of wonder: Fun to see what order your beans are going to be in. You feel like you are stuck with what you have and this can make each game play out a bit differently.

2) Meaningful/fun decisions. I feel like the decisions I make in this game don't really matter. Plant the beans with the most coins or beans? Not much of a choice most of the time

3) Player interaction:  A ton of interaction as you try to get people to trade you beans so you don't get stuck planting beans you don't want.

4) Components/artwork: The game looks awesome and I love how the beans are also the coins. The artwork and names of the beans are very amusing and fun.

5) Game length/complexity:  The game goes a bit too long for what it is. It is fun and not too hard, but can drag out a bit. Plus the sorting of cards at the beginning depending on the number of players is very tedious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Entertaining and easy to pick up. Fun cards, the artwork on which (Rio Grande version) reminds me of Too Many Cooks. There are many agonizing moments when I have to harvest a field and don't want to. Seems a bit lengthy as a filler (going through the deck a full three times) and I think is too light to be the main entree of game night... but this would make a great family game.

We immediately started playing with replica dubloons instead of using the card backs as coin markers -- this added a lot to the feel of the game, although dried beans are probably more appropriate.

[i]Update November 2006[/i] - Have the German Amigo edition with Erweiterungs. Even though we don't know German, we love this far more than the English.. 1/2/07 - upped score to 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good funny and family game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bohnanza is one of the better negotiation games I own, and a potential gateway game for non-gamers. Every negotiation game needs a mechanic that "drives" the negotiation. In Bohnanza, the mechanic is that a player draws cards on their turn, and they need to get "planted" somewhere. Every card that hits the table never goes back into a player's hand, so it is negotiation that determines where those "beans" end up.

For negotiation, I ultimately prefer Chinatown. The occasional turn in Bohnanza can sometimes be pretty flat if the wrong beans crop up or if a player's choices are no-brainers. But Bohnanza is valuable because it is flexible. It's portable, it can handle a wide range of player counts, and it's pretty easy to teach. About the only thing odd about Bohnanza for newbies is the rule that prevents ordering cards in your hand, and the oddness of drawing cards at the end of a turn. Ultimately, Bohnanza is one of those games that I never clamor for, but it always ends up getting played every once in a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
No inicio estranha-se, ao fim de umas rondas entranha-se.
Um obrigatório em qualquer ludoteca.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Finally had a chance to play this classic card game and I enjoyed it but it just took too long to play. Three times through the deck was too much even with each round taking 5 cards off of it. The game also has a lot of negotiating between players since each turn 2 cards need to be traded between the players. The gimmick here is when you plant beans you can only play from the front of your hand, but when you trade you can trade from anywhere in your hand so it's advantageous to trade and negotiate as much as you can. I liked the idea of this, but it just started feeling repetitive towards the latter half and I was beginning to wish it was over a little faster.

RATING: 9
We first played this with 2 players and didn't see what all the fuss was about.  (It was also annoying to read through the rules and then find that most of the rules were different for 2.)  However, we then played with 5 and everybody loved it!  Even the people who don't usually like games wanted to play again and again.  Keeping our cards in the order drawn was the biggest adjustment for everyone, but we quickly caught on.  Since then, we've played with 3 and 7, and it seems to help to be up on the higher end of the range.  The attitudes of the players makes a big difference too; the game is a blast if people are willing to give it a chance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Interesting card game which heavily features trading.  Only game I know of in which you cannot shuffle the order of your hand of cards as the order dictates what beans you have to deal with.

Basic idea is that you plant beans in a field.  You only have two fields at a time and fields can only hold one type of bean.  The more beans you plant in the field, the more valuable the field becomes when you harvest.  However, you have to deal with some random beans on your turn.  If you are unable to plant them in a current field or pawn them off to an opponent, then you will be forced to harvest a field before you want to.

A lot of trades end up being something like:
Player 1: "You trade me your wax bean, and, in return, I'll take your wax bean off your hands for you"
Player 2: "Deal"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
A gateway, light trading game that features hand management and set collection as its primary mechanics.

I imagine the appeal of this is mainly that it can be played with non-gamers, and as that weight of game goes, this isn't something I dislike intensely. That said, there are also other games that do similar things that I like a lot more (i.e.: Siedler).

I think the best thing in this game is the card art, which is whimsical and cute. If you like the basic game mechanics, but want something depthier, Oltremare is highly suggested, particularly the first edition with the tiny board.

RATING: 5
OK game but a little light for my taste.

NB
I'm becomming aware that abstract games are not my taste and this refects in my opinion of many games).  The theme on many simple games are painted on to level I find difficult.

Games in this grouping:
Taluva
Lost Cities
Bohanza
Jet Set
Junta
Enemy in Sight
Naval War

Some more complex game have a level of abstration that does not meet my expectation for the theme/subject etc.  This makes the game a less compelling experience.

Games in this grouping:
Elder Signs
Reef Encounter
Modern Naval Battles
The Fury of Dracula

My enthusiasm for these games is limited by a level of abstraction that challenges my taste and my rating reflects this.

RATING: 7
Enero 08. Generación X, pagado con su abono de 10% por compra (10,50)

Cada jugador planta judias en 2 o 3 campos para venderlas. Cuantas mas judias de una misma variedad se tengan plantadas, mas oro se ganara en la venta. El objetivo es ganar la mayor cantidad de oro plantando, cosechando y vendiendo judias.
Lo que hace diferente a este popular juego de cartas es que no puedes reordenar tu mano. Tienes que jugar tus cartas en el orden en que te llegan. Para poder deshacerte de cartas que no quieras plantar o conseguir judias que te interesen es fundamental la negociacion con los demas jugadores.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very simple hand-rigging game with a cute theme. fairly straightforward to teach to new players. Each turn you need to plant the first bean card in your hand and may plant an additional one - you rig your hand by trading with other players before your turn rolls around. The player with the most coins (earned by harvesting sets of planted beans) after the deck has been cycled through 3 times is the winner.

Makes for a nice party game - because of the trading there is always something to do even if it isn't your turn. 

After playing this a fair few times I am starting to find the lack of mechanics uninteresting compared to other games.

This is the first ever "new" board game we played one night at UQ with some other students we met.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Excellent game. Simple premise but meaningful decisions. 

It does have a few weaknesses:

1. It really isn't a short game although it feels like it should be. In a competitive game this isn't a problem but if things aren't cutthroat then the ending is a long time coming. 

2. Poor trades can really screw up the competitiveness. I often find myself intervening and pleading people to be more stingy. The trading can feel trivial to players but it is the most important part of the game. It's more an issue with players than the game, but is nearly always an issue.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

I don't care for the machanic where everyone is required to add cards to one side of their hand, remove from the other, and never rearrange.

RATING: 4
Not sure what to make of this after an initial go. Only when seeing it actually played did I begin to understand what was going on, but the ceaseless trading, cajoling and begging began to grate on my nerves sooner than I expected it would. If every trading round was forced to be concluded in 30 seconds or so it might be a somewhat fun game, but in its current inception it just failed interest me much. The idea of not being able to rearrange your hand is novel, I'll give the designer that, but at the same time I wonder how many people secretly cheat and move desirable cards to the front of their deck. Doing so will break the game quite easily.

RATING: 10
We like this game very much, but we don't care for the two-player rules (the "bean duel") at all.  The fun does depend somewhat on who is playing (but what game is fun when one or more players complain throughout?).  We especially enjoy the player interaction required to negotiate trades.  Most of the people we have convinced to try the game loved it, but a few protested that they were confused the whole time.  The cards are clever and funny and listening to the game is a great enticement for other potential players nearby. Our rating is only 2 for the two-player version.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
Absolutely a first rate card game.  It's a lot of fun.  Even people who don't really like to play games enjoy this one.  The best thing about the game is that it is wonderfully social.  The trading/donating aspect of every turn produces a lot of interaction between the players.  Also, it's a game that pretty much anyone can win - regardless of level of experience with the game.  While it is far from my favourite game, it's a must-have for anyone's game collection and that is a big part of why I have rated it a 10.  What it does, it does very well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We've played this game many times now. This is a really great game. The game allows for many players (2-7). It’s a card game that can be set up quickly. This game could become  a family favorite. 

	• It has infinite replayability
	• Excellent player involvement - trading keeps players involved for every player turn. 
	• Multiple ways to win - start a 3rd bean field? 
	• Good game for non-gamers

There were a couple of parts to the game that at first seemed a little arbitrary - card order and donating. But once you get a few rounds into the game you realize that the constraint of card-order forces to you think and strategize. Donating cards to others it critical for building the right hand before its your turn. 

One downside: I don't like the art. The pictures are campy and ridiculous which doesn't match the classic nature of the game. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game has been played countless times amongst family, friends and co-workers.  I haven't kept track of the games or dates, but 25+ is a good conservative figure.

Gameplay is fast, interaction is frequent and often humerous as each player attempts to get the deal that works best for them.  Simple rules and short playtime makes this a good travel and filler game for all levels of gamers, that I know.

RATING: 7
Components: Wonderful artwork on high-quality cards.

Fan edition: Wide variety of entertaining cards, but it makes it more confusing, less unified, and the cards lack the numbers indicating how many cards there are of each type. The fan edition is practically unplayable.

Experience: The mechanics are quite simple, but choosing how best to manage my hand of cards, and maximize trades, is a true delight. There isn't enough continuity from turn to turn; I'd enjoy it more if I had a long-term strategy, rather than just working with what I've got from round to round. This game has lost its shine over the years.

First Played: 2002-01-01
Last Played: 2015-10-19
Plays (30):
? players: 15
3 players: 2
4 players: 6
5 players: 4
6 players: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a fine card game with an original card playing mechanic i.e. cards must be played in the order they are received.  The cards also serve the purpose of scoring i.e. the reverse side of the cards show "gold coins" that are collected during the game.  I would have rated this one higher but this really isn't a 2 player game as advertised (2-7 players) and is merely average with 3 players.  I think the game only really begins to shine with 4 players.  There are many more opportunities for competitive negotiation and clever trading with more players (5+). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

28-1-11  
A great trading game for multiplayer play. Can get slowed down as folk want something more equitable or favourable and can't get it (because generally-small hand sizes don't give a massive amount to trade with).

Deliberation can slow the game down but generally a fun, social event with a lot of luck. COMPLETELY different game between 2 and 5/4p.

RATING: 7
Summer 2012: I only have ~20 plays behind me when writing this, but this game is amazing. Okay, strategically it's pretty basic and easy to figure out, but for me the most important thing is that everyone is having fun.

And that has happened every time. I've introduced it to people who've never played anything and I've played it with our regular group. I've played it with over 20 different people and every single one has enjoyed it. 

The game feels different with different people. It brings out the personalities of people in a new way and it's interesting to see how their haggling skills evolve.

It's an amazing game and I'm not completly sure how to rate it yet. I think when I get bored to it, I'll really get bored.

Edit July '13, 8 -> 7: It has gotten a bit dull. Maybe I've gotten an overdose, but it lasted surprisingly long as a game I was willing to play.

RATING: 6
[2011-08-11 Rating: 4 -> 6]
After playing this game with someone who likes the game, I did enjoy it more than back in 2005. I'm still not really sure about this one but I had the feeling, that my old rating of 4 wasn't appropriate anymore.

[2005]
Well, after buying and playing this game I realized that I don´t like pure trading games. Somehow I can´t see what I have to do in order to win.

Nevertheless I guess the game itself can be quite good if it is played with the right people, whereas I have to say that it is quite boring with just three players.

So if you really like trading games with simple rules you should give this a try. If you don´t like them, you should play a round before you decide if you want to spent the money and get a copy.

Since I could be talked into playing a round occasionally I´ll rate it 4.

RATING: 9
A very fun game and one of the most popular games I've ever purchased. Embraced by everyone I've ever played with. Some complain the play is pretty mechanical, but that would imply that there would be more luck involved. That seems unlikely, considering how rarely I actually win this game.

Just re-rated it after starting to play again and bumped it back up to a 9. This is a true classic and probably has given me more hours of gaming fun per dollar than any other game ever. We actually have worn out one set and had to replace it with a new one.

RATING: 6.5
If haggling is something you enjoy then Bohnanza is for you! I really like the 'required planting' mechanic and the situations it creates. Games of this nature can only be played so often as they devolve into arguments and 'you scratch my back' agreements that tend to last beyond the game. This is a light, filler game that may seem better through my nostalgia goggles than it actually is.

Why this isn't a 10:
-> Game success depends on others' willingness to trade you for what you (and they) need
-> Longer playtime for what it is
-> Waxy for a Stinky? Anyone?

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cute little trading game about growing beans. Players must plant beans from their hand of bean cards, and nuture them into large beanfields. These beans can be harvested for &quot;coins&quot;, and different beans can be worth more or less coins depending on their rarity. Also, on every player&#039;s turn, two beans are turned up for trading with the other players. Most coins wins after three times through the deck. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is a fun trading game that definitely speeds up as you go through it and everyone gets the hang of it.  Fans of Pit will like this one, though it isn't quite as frantic and there aren't any bears to pass off to anybody.  If you don't like trading games or you aren't interested in being vocal about making trades, you may not like this game.  A lot more fun than its theme (bean planting?) might suggest. Plus you can play with a lot of players!!

RATING: 5.5
This was another early Eurogame purchase for me, back when the cards were still in german.  Affectionately known as "the bean game" amongst my family and friends, this gets requested and played often, and some of my friends have gone on to buy their own copy.  Easy to teach to non-gamers, and very very portable!

Overall though, I feel this game hasn't aged well, I rarely want to play it in comparison to other card games.  I would rather play Citadels or No Thanks.

Update: gave it to my sister as a gift.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Crowd pleaser. Who knew that bean farming was a universally loved theme? I think the gameplay is a little lacking*, but it's a nice background for a relaxing social gathering (if everyone is generally cooperative). The game itself would probably be more interesting if played aggressively, but this game would not be a top choice for me when looking for a challenge.

*I think the problem is that players have such a large incentive to dump cards they don't need that it's always a buyer's market. This makes it harder to negotiate on the relative value of each card (e.g. the cocoa bean is much more valuable than the coffee bean, but it's hard to get anything better than a 1:1 trade because each play risks really screwing up their hand if they don't get rid of the card they don't need, so any trade is "usually" better than no trade IMO).

I just bumped the rating up on this one because I think the variant that allows trading future cards will fix the problem I was having that the trades were hard to make equitable. Unfortunately, I'm not surprised that I didn't naturally think of this myself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Games can get fast and furious, and are quite fun. I forget how enjoyable this game can be.

RATING: N/A
#: Best 5, 2-7
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Fast and Fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
+ This is a great gateway game and I enjoy it very much for the trading aspect alone. The people I introduce it to enjoy it as well, especially when they get a good deal. Since the game is fairly compact, this is one of my go to games when leaving the house.

- In this game, there is one awkward card rule. You cannot rearrange or shuffle your cards that you have been dealt. You must leave the cards in that order. And that can be hard for some people to coupe with, because when you are dealt a hand cards you automatically want to set them in a certain order.
Another item would be at the higher player counts, at 7 players you start out with 3 cards if you are the first player. The next player has 4, the player after has 5, and the rest has 6 cards. And if you completed all your trading after the first 3 people, you end up waiting around before it is your turn again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Re-playing this after years has upgraded my opinion of it. I'm still not exactly a fan, but there is definitely a game here. The restrictions are a useful way to encourage trading, but chance of the draw and others' ebbing of stubbornness will overpower strategy and persuasion.

RATING: 7
Fun hand management card game that encourages banter between players. Tough and rewarding to figure out how to plant the beans you want and get the useless ones out of your hand, while at the same time trying not to give the opponents what they need to win. 

It has the potential to become one of those games where one player doesn't care - then that player gives all of his or her good cards to a friend, and that's always annoying. So play with the right people. :)

RATING: 9

I love this little bean trading game, sometimes it can get a little cutthroat - but that just makes it better!

Plays fantastically well with literally any number of allowed players, and its slightly different depending on how many you play with.

Still can't believe the designer of this great classic is also the father or Agricola!

RATING: 8

Overall, I think it is a good game, but the people I play with like the game more than I do.

RATING: 6
Good bargaining skills tested. You play a bean farmer planting beans for which you get gold when you harvest. You only have 2 fields and can only plant a type of bean in it at any time. The more you have before you harvest, the more gold you get. You do this by trading and bargaining for the beans you want from the other players. Plays well with not less than 4, I find it best with 5.

RATING: 7
A fun game, but one that I'm more likely to break out with family than the game-group. Very torn on the 'static hand order' rule - fascinating idea in theory, but difficult to execute. Some people have trouble remembering this rule, or may tend to drop cards, essentially breaking the game.

Family weight comes through in that the pathway forward is generally pretty clear - decisions aren't tough, and trades are pretty easy to pull off.

RATING: 5
To maintain endgame tension, it appears that everyone needs to deny leaders what they want. If one person doesn't do that, they may make it too easy for a leader to stay ahead.

The game seemed long with 5. Perhaps using the original card distribution would help?

The game only occasionally created opportunities for two players to fight over a trade. It didn't appear to allow players to choose high-risk, high-reward strategies. Instead, points accumulated somewhat linearly.

RATING: 6.73
Wicked, almost party game of hectic haggling and banter. Silly bean vendors are trying their best to grow large and rare beanstalks in order to get the most money, but beans are only grow if they manage to persuade other players to give them their beans, if possible for free. It lasts tiny bit longer than it should for a light game, but it's OK, nothing more.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Hand management during market phase when players have the only window to get read of useless beans from their hand, but only if the other player accepts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

Bohnanza is a friendly game but still gives you room to negotiate the big deal every so often. Seems to play best at around 5 and can run a little long for what it is.

RATING: 7
I've played this game way too much because everyone loves it.  This is an excellent seven player card game.  It might not have the sex appeal of 7 Wonders (yes, I'm looking at you Altar), but it's a lot more fun.  It's a raucous wheelin' and dealin' trade fest, and if you don't like that than you're just an old smelly stink bean, or maybe just someone who doesn't like trading games.  If you do like trading games and are also looking for a game that scratches the seven player itch then this is the one I'd recommend.  Everyone I've played with has loved it.

RATING: 9
Possibly my favourite group game, although hard to keep players reminded of not rearranging their hands. Disputes can break out when a bean is in demand, a real treat to watch everyone bidding over a single bean, even better to watch someone begging to give one away for free. A very far cry from Rosenberg's most popular games, but my personal favourite. Everyone likes this one, a must for any collection.

30-45m, best with 3-5 players. 10+ plays.

RATING: 5
Lots of interaction through trading, but it seems to me a dated-design. Theme is sort of silly, but the small-sized box means the game is portable. The strict hand order (cards cannot be realigned in your hand - honour system) is neat in theory, but doesn't seem to work all that well in practice (with certain players).  Also, it's sort of a dumb rule and I think there are better trading games to play instead for ages 13+.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First time through with 2p - good game mechanics, fun artwork, and fast play.  The read through of the rules gave pause...how could this be any fun at all?  But, once on the table, the stilted, awkward seeming rules evolved into a smooth, fun, very engaging bean farming experience. While fun with 2, glimpses of the potential for fun multi-player interactions (memories of family games of Pit) make me eager to play with a larger group.

Much more fun with four, five and six players! Now I understand the affection for this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
There are many games that have a trading element. Bohnanza forces players to trade, a lot, it they want any chance at winning. 

Some complain that Bohnanza is mostly luck. While there is a lot of luck, a player's skill in trading is very important. This may not typically be considered a skill in most games. Victories may be attributed to luck, that in actuality should be attributed to trading skill.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Pros
--Game engages every player every turn of the game (phone-during-game deterrent?)
--Creates a story/rivalries through deals that did or did not happen
--Very satisfying feeling when plans pan out

Cons
--Luck dependent
--A little long for how simple the game is

Overall, this game isn't so bad.  I don't see all the "hilarity and fun" that people are talking about when playing, although the trading and coaxing can be a boon.

RATING: 9
Bohnanza does a great job sucking out all the negative vibes from the negotiation genre. The idea that winning in Bohnanza (at least in my group) requires a level of niceness- but not too much or too little- is nothing short than a breakthrough. If this game was what American families played, I think America would be a lot more game friendly.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Very interactive and chaotic game with an unusual mechanic for the order of the cards in your hand, that I found rather hard to teach, it being often considered as a typical gateway game. The helpful play mats in the BGG file section help a lot to bring some order to the game. There are other card games that our gaming group likes a lot better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like trading games, and this isn't a bad one, but it has one fatal flaw - it's too luck dependent to be a serious strategy game, but it's too long and complicated to be a light fun game to pull out with a group of non-gamers.

It's not the the rules are really super complicated, but they are very unintuitive, which makes it really hard for someone who isn't accustomed to wrapping their head around it.  Once you do, they work well, and create a good play experience.  But there is a learning curve.

For serious gamers, of course, the learning curve is no problem - it simpler than most serious strategy games. But with serious gamers, I would rather be playing a serious strategy game.  I got this to play with non-gaming friends and relatives, and for them it is really a bit too daunting.  

Still, if you can get past that, and find a group for which it works, it's reasonably fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[5 plays] A jolly card game.  Don't be put off by the strange bean farming theme; it's basically a trading game.  I like the unusual mechanism of not being able to rearrange your cards and having to plant them in the order drawn.  When you read the rules and it says to go through the deck three times, you may think the game will be long, but on the second and even more on the third time through, there will be so many fewer cards in the deck that it really zips along.  The game is well-produced, though I really don't care for some of the more crudely humorous art.  The only thing I really don't like about the gameplay is the way the bean cards double as gold.  This means that beans are subtracted from the deck whenever anyone earns some gold.  This either messes up the otherwise-clearly-known card distribution in random, unpredictable, and mostly unknown ways, or, if people are really attentive to this and manipulate it deliberately (though there's very limited scope to do so), it adds screwage and memory elements that don't seem to really belong to this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

RATING: 7
great casual game but can take long if players keep bickering
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great card game about trading and collecting sets of beans then "harvesting" them for various amounts of coins. The player with the most coins at the end of the game wins. The trading mechanics coupled with the player's set hand order makes this game shine. You see, the cards in your hand must stay in the order in which they were dealt. On your turn you must play the first card in your hand. So it is often to your advantage to trade cards in your hand to other players for nothing in return. That way the cards in your hand are useful and in a favorable order. 

At least in my group this was a very light game. Players were generous with their trading so everyone got the particular bean they were going for at the time. I don't think you can get too greedy with trading in this game because if you don't get rid of unmatched cards you will be forced to harvest often with minimal gain.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The cards are colorful depictions of beans in various descriptive poses, and the object is to make coins by planting fields (sets) of these beans and then harvesting them. To help players match their cards up, the game features extensive trading and deal making. One of the most unique features of the game is that you cannot rearrange your hand, as you need to play the cards in the order that you draw them.

RATING: 6
(As of [b]1[/b] play) A set collection game with a twist. The restriction on reordering your hand of cards makes negotiation and trading extremely important. You [i]have[/i] to help other players if you are to have any chance of winning, but such help must be carefully regulated. This adds an interesting element of negotiation that makes it much more interactive than typical set collection games. 

[b]1 year verdict:[/b] I probably wouldn't turn down a game of this, but I'm not particularly interested in playing it again.

RATING: 7.5
This is a great little social game. It's super easy to understand so I bring it out for groups of non-gamers. It's also a very friendly game, with everyone helping everyone else for the most part. It isn't really that competitive in that regard, as people are pretty unwilling to harvest fields early, so cards are gifted fairly often. This could be annoying for some competitive players who don't want to play that way, but I haven't had problems. I figure I may if I tried to play this game to win.

RATING: 7
One of our first trading games. I like the way tension is built on almost every action you do... do I trade to better my hand? will a trade really make my hand better or just benefit my opponent? what if the coco bean comes up? ooops, i can't move cards around?
It can get frustrating but it's a fun frustration (especially with a good interactive crowd).

RATING: 8
A quirky game that upends some established traditions.  You have a hand of cards, but you may not sort them.  Often you prosper by giving things away for nothing (but the recipients have to agree to take them.)  I enjoy playing from time to time just for the novelty (despite the fact that this game is 15 years old this year.)

RATING: 8
Fun set collection and negotiation game.  Works well with more than four people.  Don't ever play this game with a newly dating couple--too many opportunities for couples to "cheat" by preferring trades with their date for emotional rather than game advantage reasons.  

Have noticed that groups of women in particular enjoy this game -- probably because there's a communal aspect of benefiting your neighbor through trades at the same time as you try to do well yourself.

RATING: 9.5
Bean farming at it's best.  One of the earliest games I was introduced to in the board game hobby and a game I still get to the table at just about every board gaming event I hold.  Some would say Agricola or Caverna are Uwe's best games, but this game wins in my opinion.  Also, the edition I have handles a lot of people surprisingly well.  Be aware, this game can take a while if you have a larger group and the expansions all seem to make the game longer as well.

RATING: 8
Based on 24 plays.
+ Very good scalability. (With two players, the game is different, though) Even with 7 players, you have something to do (negotiating) most of the time.
+ Negotiation is not mandatory, but helps to play better. It's not necessary for all players to like negotiations.
> It has a silly theme. (I like, at least)
> Causes loud conversations.
- Illustrations are not of my liking (They are funny, though.)
- Includes some non-intuitive mechanics (for example, cards in hand may not be reordered).

Since 2006, updated Dec 2011.

RATING: 9
We play this one all the time.  It's a good interactive game and gets better with more people.  The interesting thing about this game, to me, is that you can't alter the order of your hand, forcing you to trade cards out of your hand in order to move needed cards to the front (and thereby allowing you to play them sooner).  One of the better $11 purchases I've ever made on anything.

RATING: 10
[b] Played 70+ times with 2p-7p.
Rating history: 10..................|9.....|10...................

Though longer than most card games, Bohnanza is the gold standard, best card game ever.[/b]

:star: bright, colourful, amusing visuals
:star: highly social trading game
:star: not a simple ruleset, but excellent payoff of ruleset vs interesting gameplay
:star: appeals to non-gamers and gamers who enjoy trading/negotiation
:star: plays up to 7 players

- a bit long for a card game of this type (but you probably won't notice)
- teach this to non-gamers is tough because of two rules: the no-rearranging rule, and the four-steps-sequence
- the 2p variant in the rules is quite terrible

GREAT NON-GAMER GAME! This is a classic, and the great intro-to-'German' card game. 2-player version lacks something, but the multiplayer game is good enough that I still enjoy playing. After playing this game with more than 30 people on different occasions, I actually played this with a gamer who didn't like it -- the first one. ((Bought from F.))

RATING: 7

Oh the agony of deciding if that 3rd field is worth it!  My only concern is the sometimes difficult rule to implement in who initiates trades (supposedly the current player but sometimes from table talk it gets murky).  But besides that, there is so much fun to be had.  Bean there and will go again.

RATING: 3
[Trading, Set Collection, Hand Management] [6P:3: 5P:3, 4P:3] Decent set collection and trading game, but really works best with six players who know how it goes and aren't shy about trading. As exciting as watching paint dry if no one wants to trade. *** UPDATE: Replays aren't kind to Bohnanza. It suffers from the "this again?" syndrome, where turns and games blur into one big mess and there isn't a decent gaming memory to be had from the whole morass. Yes, it's ok to pull it out when the clueless nongaming newbies come to visit, but every game is beginning to feel like Chinese Water Torture. "No, please, no more beans!! AAAAAAAHHHHH!" If it wasn't a gift I wouldn't own it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Must-have gateway game.  

People seem to really enjoy this, but only once they get past the unintuitive rules+mechanics, and each phase order on their turn and get their head around the fact that this is not exactly a party game. Pretty simple to teach and learn, and highly interactive because negotiations are absolutely necessary in this game. THE trading game to have. 
 
Not ingenious, not terribly deep, but still different, refreshing and fun. 

Tried the 2-player variant suggested in the Rio Grande edition. It works. Feels like a different game altogether, though. It took the negotiation aspect out, of course, but it turned into something that felt like Lost Cities with a twist: set collection + trying to not help the other player in your discards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A great filler that takes a little too long and dries out. The first handful of games were crazy wheel-and-deal affairs with salesmanship of all kinds, but after the honeymoon period (probably 10 very fun plays) we all settled into a dull "audit every trade to stop anyone from getting a leg up" strategy. Also, the late game can really drag: everyone sits around with a hand full of cards they don't want to/can't efficiently move, and fields they're happy to leave stagnant if they can just wait out the end without giving anyone else an opening. Still recommended, especially with non-gamers. One of the chief remaining thrills is finding insidious ways to fleece friends who've never played before.

One of the toughest games to rate in my collection. I look at games I've rated above it and can't say I've gotten nearly as much fun out of many of them as out of Bohnanza. The flaws do nag though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

You have to understand the counter intuitive fact that this isn't a collection game as it first seems - rather trade trade trade

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bohnanza is all about trading, plus a bit of hand management. As such, it is also probably one of the most sociable games around. You won't get a lot more interaction without resorting to an all-out brawl. Collector types will even like to play this when they are losing, and it's pretty great to introduce new people to the hobby as well. Best with 4+ players, and a lot of its flair depends on having the right group. If people don't like to barter it will be getting stale pretty quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Uwe Rosenberg hits it early out of the park with this one! Bohnanza meshes together everything I like about card games: auctioning, trading, risk, set collection.  Just puts it all together in one brilliantly satisfying game. Yeah, at its core it is still a push-your-luck game, and your card draws can either seriously hinder you or benefit you without any personal influence; but the way the cards are played out is just so brilliant that I can't imagine giving this anything other than an '8'.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I rate Bohnanza in two distinct ways, as a negotiation game, and as a gateway game.  In the latter I think Bohnanza offers a wonderful introduction to games beyond Monopoly, as it presents players with new mechanics and strong interaction. However, I sometimes find the game feels long and repetative, almost dragging at points; as this game, like most negotiation games, needs all players to be cunning and a bit cut throat.  With that said Bohnanza can be a blast, even with seasoned players but it lacks that certain something that Traders offers me. Could it be the feel of progression, and the varying options? Maybe.  Bohnanza over all is a fun time and a game I am not often going to turn away. I find the expansions pointless, and only detract from this unique original game.
