=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was one of the first (possibly the very first) "Euro" game I ever had the pleasure of playing, and my wife and our friends became obsessed with it for quite a while. It's definitely the most fun I've ever had with a pure trading game, but like other trading-heavy game experiences (Settlers) play can lead to some... ah... tensions... when folks feel slighted in trades, and of course the strongest personality tends to win in these sorts of games, but you get what you get with trading games.

Bohnanza's most ballyhooed feature is its hand constraint - cards must be kept in the order in which they were drawn, and they come out in order, first-in-first-out. This is cool and different and all, but it's also essential to the game, don't let any rebellious players bully you into changing it!

Overall, "Beans" is really a blast to play, and is a rare great game that can be played with 6 or 7 after very little "teaching", making it a great "party game alternative" if you want to introduce non-gamers to more substantial fare.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Amazing 2 systems.
1 is unique hand management and 2 is trade.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game would be too simple, except for one neat twist:  The cards that you're trying to create sets from must be played in the order you pick them up.  Another great introductory game; the extra bit of thought that's required of players shouldn't stump anyone.  A great game with 4 or 5, it comes with rules for as few as 2.  Because of the degree of player interaction required (you will not win this game if you try to rely solely on your own hand), expect a fairly long game if you play a 6- or 7-player game--at that point, it loses its "intro" appeal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
Another game that I really wanted to like but just didn't.  Of the ~15 people I have played this game with, 1 really liked it, 2-3 enjoyed it, and the rest ranged from "meh" to dislike.  The people I play with range from hardcore gamers to casual couple gamers.  I gave this game to a friend who plays with another gaming group.  They have the same opinion.

For me, the game takes WAY too long to go through the deck 3 times.  Twice seems to be about the right length.  Even then though... most people want the game to be over once through the deck.  That is a sign that people are not into the game.

This game came highly recommended online and it was cheap... so it seemed like a no brainer.  Oh well...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a perfect social game. I've played it with 5 or less people many times. ALWAYS fun. The game is brilliant. It's so satisfying to come up with new trades and bribes and bargaining approaches. It honestly never gets old. Everyone who has played this game loves it. The pattern seems to be: I take it over to a friends to play a round, they end up buying a copy.

There is A LOT of constant player to player interaction, and no down time between turns because you're usually trying to make deals with the active player. No hard feelings in the end, it's always within a few gold of each other, no one feels like a loser. Best with 3 or more. Easy to teach, quick to pick up and learn.

October 2011 -- We have enjoyed this game for many years and have had to replace several decks of cards. It is still one of the most popular of our games for our family group.

2013-November: This continues to be one of the most-played games in our collection.

RATING: N/A

Von Patricia und Thomas
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bought in February 2014.

OK, there's kind of a weird reason this has gone unplayed for a couple of years. I feel BETRAYED by this game.

I've had some great times with it - but then I discovered I was playing a rule wrong (for years!). And I like the game less with the rule fixed.

We missed that you can only harvest two or more beans - single bean fields can't be harvested unless you have no other option.

I suspect it might better played wrongly. Much easier to teach, gives you more options, makes the 3rd bean field a more balanced decision, encourages more generosity with trades (because you can accept a single card intending to immediately overplant it). For me, playing it wrongly helps reinforce what makes it fun; whereas playing correctly takes away from that.

Namely, the genius of this game is that it encourages you to be generous with trades - even to the point where you'll willingly donate cards to help other players. Which means you never get stuck in a [thing=13]Settlers of Catan[/thing]-like situation where someone insists on unreasonable trades and slows the game down.

One day I'll forgive it and play it again. But play it right or keep playing it wrong? I don't know!

The main downside is that it can run a little long. I'm not sure how much the effect on gameplay would be of only going through the deck once (rather than three times), but that might make it the perfect length.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very fun card game with nice and simple trading mechanic.

Pros:
+ Quite simple gameplay and good mechanics,
+ Nice and fun artwork, quality components (cards),
+ Theme is fun and great (farming themes are great, because they are realistic and educational in this urbanized world),
+ Trading phase makes this game fun and interactive,
+ Although game has some random chance, the order in which the cards must be kept, fixed hand management and trading chance makes this game much more strategic than random,
+ Small box which makes this game suitable for traveling around.

Cons:
- Rules are different for player variations - of course, that was made for balance, however the two player game is significantly different and does not include any trading,
- The card order keeping and some rules at the beginning is hard to get and corectly implement which makes it not very easy to explain to beginners and there are some confusing rules,
- Players should be perfectly honest in this game, otherwise the game isn't fair. Trading phase could be improved with more strict rules to avoid dishonest trading deals.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Silly, but fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Terrific trading game with broad appeal, although it sometimes seems to last a bit too long. One of my top choices for introducing non-gamers to this hobby of ours (if I can get them to look past the game's oh-so-thrilling theme of bean farming).  If you have the German edition, be sure to get the Erweiterungs Set, which tweaks the card mix according to the number of players, greatly improving the game balance.  Plays well with any number of players from three to seven, although I like it best with four or five.  With lots of players, you have to fight hard to acquire the beans you want.  With fewer players, the struggle is often just to get rid of the beans you *don't* want.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The kids love this one...well, for now anyway! And now so does my wife, more than any of us. The wheeling and dealing of the cards can be fun and painful depending on which end of the deal you're on; especially not taking cards off others which they want to give you and will not effect you in any adverse way, but if they keep the card/s they will have to plant them and wreck their other plantings. Sometimes like most card based games you may feel you're getting bad cards. However so many cards are drawn that it seems to even out well if you keep to your strategy. We play 3 player in about 45 minutes but 5 is more fun.

RATING: 6
A decent game for 4 or 5 players. With 6 or 7 it overstays its welcome, because the negotiations take too long to reach an end. With 3 players there is the opposite problem: not enough people to negotiate with. Forget about it with 2 players: it is boring as hell.

People seem to really get into it from the first play, but since the mechanism is always the same, it wore out after a dozen plays. Not enough meat here to become a keeper.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In our group this is called “the bean game” for obvious reasons. If you look past the silly theme for the game (which however is well integrated) there are quite some interesting decisions. What makes the game is that you can’t reorganize your hand, since that will make you trade away beans that will be away in your hand. If you do it properly and other players are willing you don’t need the third bean field.

I like the free wheeling and dealing in this game as it is to the point and players usually know what other players will want to have. In other games these kinds of decisions can drag the game out, but it seems to be more concentrated here. This isn’t a heavy game by any stretch and there is a lot of luck involved, but at the same time it is a player driven game.

I found it to play best with four or five players. With more players there are too much beans in play making the decisions more trivial and with less there seems to be too little chaos.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've played with the maximum and the minimum and enjoy them both. I've played the "official" 2-player rules included with the game and our own same-rules-as-for-more-players variant and enjoy them both. I've played with family and youth group kids and have enjoyed them both. So basically, I've thoroughly enjoyed this game! I like the interaction, the silly artwork and the entire premise of farming beans. It's always a hoot to introduce it to people who ask what the game is about: "Bean farming!" I always say with a smile.

RATING: 9
As much as I enjoy this game, I can never win it. You're a bean farmer. And you plant beans! What kind of beans? Drunk beans, cowboy beans, kick in the nuts beans and other funny ones. You'll be laughing throughout the whole game. Plant your beans right and you'll make lots of money. Trade, barter, watch your fields and you'll be the richest bean farmer in town. Very fun game, especially with a lot of people!

RATING: 10
Perhaps my favourite game of all-time.

I *strongly* recommend playing with no more than five players and removing the 4s, 22s, and 24s from the English-language version (they make the game outstay its welcome).

RATING: 7
An interesting little trading card game with the added twist of not being able to rearrange your hand once dealt. Quite enjoyable and pretty quick once everyone knows what they are doing. Probably best suited to around 4 or 5 players though.

Edit: Just found out that we've been playing this game wrong for over a year. That's what happens when I don't read the rules for myself and just take someone else's word for it! Not the first time this has happened either so I should have learned my lesson. In any case I actually don't like the game as much with the correct rules and have dropped it's rating down accordingly.

Edit: Still a great game now I've had time to get used to the proper rules, but can be slightly long for what should be a filler game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating for 3+ players (found 2-player a bit 'meh').

A game that keeps you constantly engaged, throws frequent 'should-I, shouldn't I?' decisions at you, and keeps the whole table talking. Just great fun. Worked magnificently with my non-gaming parents, and is jostling with Ticket to Ride as the default game to introduce people to the hobby with (only the game length prevents it being automatic winner).

Shy of being a nine mainly because with such narrow scoring margins, a few lucky draws can skew the game in a player's favour (the other players' trading power should be able to rebalance it, but it's hard to tell the difference between piles of 'coin' cards with only a few cards between them).

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have had some really fun sessions playing this game.  This has some wonderful player interactivity.  This will be one of my go-to games for a non-gaming, but lively, crowd.

Has type of luck as any other card game.  The interesting constraint is that of playing your hand like a queue (cards must be played from the front of your hand and drawn cards must be added at the back of your hand).  You may however, trade away cards that you don't want in your hand.  These two things together create a situation that really compels you trade pretty agressively at times.  So things can get pretty animated!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Great fun with the right crowd.  People who complain about its lack of depth are missing the point.  People who complain about the game dragging on to long should just end the game the first or second time the draw deck is depleted.  People who complain about not liking trading games shouldn't play trading games.  If you ever play games with a group of non-gamers, Bohnanza is a no-brainer, especially with its $15 (or less) price tag.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simple to teach and quick to play.  There is little down time because each player has to pay attention to possible trades at all times.  Bohnanza is still one of the best trading games ever designed.  The unique rule of not being able to re-order cards is off-putting to new players, but after a couple of rounds, they quickly get the hang of it.  Knowing when to cash out of a bean type is key to winning.  Nearly every game has come down to only a few points separating first and second (one reason that I never buy the third bean field).

I've played with player counts from 3 to 7.  While 3 is ok, it is not optimum.  4 is better, but the game plays best at 5 or 6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Boonanza
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
B
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The scores are often very low (15-20 points) and close in this game, often ending in a tie.  It sometimes seems like lots of work (making offers for trades) for little reward.

This is an unusual game in that each player's hand of cards is a FIFO queue. There are times that it's meaningful to donate a card to another player for free, just to get rid of the card that must be played next and to free up the subsequent cards.  Similarly, trading a card for the identical card is also useful at times, because traded cards can come from anywhere in one's hand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Bean planting game. 

Best recommended with 4+ players.

Players MUST play cards in order from their hand and MUST plant at least one bean(card) from their hand and may plant a second bean if they want. 

Draw and display two bean cards and discuss with other players if they want the bean. Otherwise you will be forced to plant those beans. Players may coordinate to trade cards from their hand from any order to help them time their bean planting.

This is a game with lots of trading and interaction for micro managing your fields. I have not played 7 players before and would definately find it amusing if I say myself. 

Like the idea, but the time displayed on the box varies depending on the players and how long each player takes to trade their beans hahaha!

Fun party game but remember trading is crucial in this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Fun bean planting and trading game with some fun dynamics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This excellent little game packs a lot of decision and play into a pack of cards!  I have the Bohnapart and HighBohn expansions, and have not played them yet.  

The game itself is simple, but the enjoyment comes from player interraction.  This is the closest to a cooperative game as any competition can get, and it really works on your trading skills.  I have found very few people (gamers and non-gamers) who do not enjoy the game. 

As you harvest, the deck gets smaller, which drastically changes end-game tactics as well as accelerates the game end.  I have to constantly tell new players that the rules of "Shuffle and play through the deck 2 more times" will go much faster than they would expect.  (In most cases, the last 2 shuffles take significanly less time than the first one alone!)

Downside:  It is so difficult to keep people from rea-aranging their hands.  I bought 8 "kiddy" card hand holders (the circular type) and enforce thier use to help prevent hand arrangements.  Also, some people want a tactical game with little player involvement and this is definitely not their game.  Finally, the Bohnapart expansion turns this into a board game, and I frankly don't see the point to that and will probably never play it for that reason.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
For me Boonanza is all about frustration, I'm not the best deal-maker and most of the time I am not capable of getting good trades with fellow players. But that is what makes it a good game for me, it's exciting to see what cards you'll get and how it will all play out. You can get Lucky with your cards and won't need to trade at all on your way to victory but most of the time that's not the case. This game is more about playing your opponents and tricking them for your advantage than it is a game about playing cards. This game sat unplayed on my shelves for a little under a year, but it definetly deserves more attention. It's quick and fun.

RATING: 7
Todo un clásico, me encanta sus ilustraciones y se tiende a memorizar todos los nombres. Es un juego que se necesita de plantar y cosechar frijoles, requiere de negociar y comerciar con el resto de los jugadores, en ocasiones se necesita de hacer crecer los cultivos de los oponentes para no perder los de uno.

Un juego divertido, pero se necesita de poner tiempo límite a las negociaciones, en especial con bastantes jugadores. Le he agregado un par de expansiones que le dan diversidad y ofrecen otros modos de juego.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
First played Oct 23rd, 2007. This is a quick learn 5min to learn 45min to play for 5-6 players. This is a negotiation game. Everyone is given a number of cards to start the game with (3-6). On your turn you must play/plant your top card and may play the second top card. Next you turn over the top two cards from the deck and use them or auction/trade them off. Sometimes you may want to simply give them away because you will have to plant them if you can't give them away, potentially forcing an early sell of an existing bean, possibly for zero. For the 3rd phase of your turn you draw 4 cards to refill your hand. If you know someone who has it, give it a try, otherwise I wouldn't bother.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Got it from C & M as a graduation present (grad school).  First played with Bec, Brad, Scott, Becky.  Took a long time, but didn't feel like it... very fun and easy to play.

RATING: 7.5
Plays extremely well. The good thing is that the mechanics are so straightforward that the heart of the game, where most time is spent is in free form trading. This one is always fun, but given that it's not very competitive, it is too long for its own sake.

The reasons I am not rating this higher are:
1. After not that many sessions, I don't find myself eager to come for more.
2. Players can shut a player out and then the game just gets nasty - no fun at all. This is nastier than your typical leader bashing.

Ideal Players: 4-6

Description: Plant your beans, and harvest them to get gold. Be careful, because you can only plant two types.

Pro: Light and easy. Fun bean art. Neat choices about whether to give away good beans or throw away beans already planted.

Con: Not much depth. Cards re-use the same art.

Strategy: 3.5
Luck factor: 2.5 - if you plan well, randomness wouldn't trouble you much.
Players interaction: Very High Active. A must for the strategy.
Play/Wait Ratio: Medium-Low. Even when it's not your turn, you have interaction with the active player. 
Replayability: 4. Quick and fun.

RATING: 4
A pure trading game, with some of the most arbitrary mechanics I have seen. Why do I receive two free beans that I have to trade or plant? Why do I have to go through my hand in order? Why can't I just toss a bean instead of planting it? The answer to all of these questions is "So that the game will work." 

I like games with trading in them, but I also need something else to be working toward. Also, some correlation with the real world would be nice.

A personal inspiration, Uwe Rosenberg here looks at cards like few others look at them.  Always willing to play this game, a game where trading is an inescapable part of gameplay.  Very clever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It took us far too long to get this to the table... The theme is what kept it away (bean farming? really?) but once we started playing the first time, Kel commented that she wished she wouldn't have turned down the game so many times in the past.  

I think this one is destined to be [b]the[/b] game we play when we have a bunch of people over.  There is soooo much interaction between all the players.  

The rules were a bit confusing at first, but after about two times around the table in our first game we were set and the game really flew...

The above may be a bit of a mistatement though as sometimes a player's turn can drag for a long time while particularly big deals are being made.  This doesn't strictly equate to downtime though, as you usually have to pay close attention to what people are trading in order to possibly try to wrangle yourself into a deal. For example, in most games I feel fairly comfortable getting up from the table to get a snack, check on the kids, or use the bathroom...  not so here as you never know what trade you might be missing out on (wait, did you say you were looking for red beans? well...).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Sometime after a heated game of Bohnanza I just HATE the people I played with and there are about 5 minutes where we all look like we're about to punch each other in the face.  Yet, unlike with most activities that inspire this sort of emotion, it never takes long for us to move on to something else and remember the game fondly.  My friends and I still recall the implications of the Garden Bean Debacle of '09 even though I no longer have any idea of how it started.  It takes a good game to leave such a lasting impression on its players.

RATING: 7
Bohnanza is a solid choice for players getting into modern games. The interactive nature of the game - the wheeling and dealing for the best trade - provides the main appeal. It's not a perfect game (the awkward rules about harvesting single beans are necessary but difficult to explain and luck of the draw can provide just enough push to win the game), but I usually enjoy it when it hits the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I play the 2-player variant with my wife quite a lot, and I don't really enjoy it.  The most important aspect of the game - the card trading - is lost, meaning that your fate is highly dependent on what cards you draw.  The "flip three cards and pull matches out of the trash" rule can also be ridiculous at times.  If I cash out 12 Coffee Beans, then flip over a coffee bean (which is very likely), I end up getting eight of them back (four turned into gold).  This rule can make or break your game, and it's difficult to use tactically/strategically.  I'm really disappointed with games that throw in a 2-player variant that doesn't play at all like the core game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My family has recently been loving this game. I love that in order to do well, you ultimately have to give others cards that they want for next to nothing.

RATING: 7
As many have said, it's the most fun you'll ever have growing beans. It started off a little slow our first game, but after we figured things out everyone had a great time.

This one tops my list of, "games I played incorrectly that completely changed the feel of the game." We played several times before realizing you can't uproot a bean field with only one bean in it. (I didn't figure this out until I was reading an interview with the designer where he casually mentioned that rule.) Makes maintaining your fields much more difficult... but that's not a bad thing.

RATING: 5.5
2013-03-22

Initial Rating: 7.5 (August 2010)

Bohnanza is a brilliant negotiation game, however I almost never want to play it even though I love negotiating games. Weird uh? I have bought 3 copies of it and I have sold them all, in fact I still have an expansion but not the base game.  

Still I recognize and respect Bohnanza, it is a great game, easy to play and teach, it can accommodate a large number of players and it is perfect to introduce new gamers to our beloved hobby. It is very group dependent, if you like negotiation this is a must buy. (I will buy my fourth copy soon.)

As I almost never want to play it, I’m downgrading its rating so it matches the BGG rating system. 

Current Rating: 6.0

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I like this game. It's simple to explain and has a comfortable learning curve for most players. Basic strategy is made apparent early on in most games with new players. More complicated strategies exist but require some guesswork and risk-assessment. 

The theme is goofy but fun and accessible for the average person. It works from two to seven players but I feel most comfortable with 4-5 players. 

I'd suggest this game pretty quickly for non-gamers or new gamers. It's relatively quick with experienced players and still involved enough to include some strategic complications.

Edit:
I've moved it up a little because I find that it is increasingly requested and, yet, still very enjoyable for me.

RATING: 9
Highly enjoyable. My wife and I have as much fun playing 2 player as we do multiplayer. 

A very easy game but a very difficult game to teach. The mechanics aren't difficult but for some reason it is hard to teach to people. It's also a little difficult to show them how fun it will be when they learn...a little hard sometimes convincing your beer swilling pals that this little "bean game" is going to be worth their while to learn.

If you can overcome the cutesy theme and the "not hard but tricky" mechanics/strategies of the game it's a real blast to play. It has become a family favorite and it's one of the few that my mother will actually request.

RATING: 6
This is a game that lives on the silliness that can ensue.  I haven't been able to play it with adults, since most of them scoff at the theme and dismiss it out of hand.  When I play with (middle school) kids, I find the game diverting, but not incredibly more so than gin or rummy.  It does work well with the kids, however.

Update:  I finally got to play this with adults.  After 5 plays in two weeks, I think the 6 rating is accurate.  It is too chaotic for my tastes, and even with adults, the trading tends to make the game too easy.  I think the latter complaint is the result of group-think (we could all choose to be more cut-throat in our trading), but everyone at the table must play that way for it to be viable.  Overall, it's so-so.

Family game from Uwe Rosenberg
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Very tight design, with more layers than meets the eye. Play is a unique experience due to the frustration of needing to donate away cards you don't want to plant, and strategically not accepting donations. You're always feeling you're losing, and scores tend to be very close decided in the end-game. The negotiation is very controlled (only with dealer), which I like.  Going through the discards three times adds a deck-building aspect which often decides the game ("if I cash in x, it will come up again for others y time away").  A "brainy" family game that almost has a whiff of Knizia to it. And you use the back of cards to score, doesn't get more elegant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Beans, beans... this is a fun game with simple rules, yet a nice amount of strategy.  There's a reason this is considered a "classic".  Really like this one!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]1997 Spiel des Jahres Recommended[/url][/b]

Ever imagined you were a bean farmer? Sure, who hasn't. You got your red beans, your green beans, your black-eyed beans, your coffee beans. But where to plant them. In this card game, smart sowing lets you reap big rewards. Plant the beans you do want, and trade the beans you don't want to the other players. Adding to the realism of the game, the one who ends up with the most money wins.

Players: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7
Time: 45 min
Mechanics: [property=2040][/property], [property=2004][/property], [property=2008][/property]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 6
Played heavily, but then we discovered Res Publica which now receives far heavier play.  Bohnanza is about trade in the face of oversupply.  Res Publica is trade in a situation of undersupply, both of desired commodities and information.  I tend to prefer games in which there are insufficient resources.

RATING: 9.3
Bohnanza is really awesome.  There's something so great about a card game where players are able to chat and make trades (or donations if you're me) and just allow time to pass in a really enjoyable card game.  I love the idea of forced planting and allowing for a second planting if wanted.  Add to that that really amazing way the cards push toward the front of your hand for planting, whether you want them to or not.  I really love this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Age could be from 9 years up, not 12. Lots of fun with kids.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Bean farming? For real? Well, it turns out this game is a hell of a lot of fun. The rules take mere seconds to explain and it consists of a deck of cards, so you could take it anywhere. It only takes a few turns to get a feel for how to get clunkers out of your hand to keep them from fouling up your queue. As such, you can demand things for free or even give them away for free as circumstances allow. 

The box suggestion of ages 12 and up seems overly cautious--I'm sure you could have a blast with younger kids.

RATING: 8
Played this with 5 and it was a blast. Highly social with enough decision-making to keep it interesting. It's ostensibly a trading game, but with the ability to give cards away, the trading is very easy and does not bog down play with difficult negotiations. Usually the card you want is available from someone or it isn't.

The expansions look weird and unappealing to me.

[u]METRICS THAT DON'T NECESSARILY AFFECT OVERALL RATING[/u]:
Weight: (Very light) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Very Heavy)
Conflict: (No Conflict) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Lots of Conflict)
Luck v. Strategy: (Luck-Heavy) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Purely Strategy)
Theme: (Abstract) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Lots of Theme)
Interaction: (Little Interaction) :star::star::star::star::star: (Lots of Interaction)
Learning Curve: (Easy to learn) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Hard to learn)

[u]METRICS THAT MAY AFFECT OVERALL RATING[/u]:
Component Quality: (Cheapish bits) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (Awesome bits)
Fun Factor: (I think it's no fun) :star::star::star::star::halfstar: (I think it's LOTS of fun)
Value for the Money: (A waste) :star::star::star::star::star: (Worth it)

RATING: 8
It's funny how you can be not very keen on a game mechanic and yet when it's done well in a game it really fits it can still be very good. I'm not a great fan of negotiation games, but I really like Bohnanza.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Clever, fun, strategic.  What more could you want?  This is simply a superbly designed game - no extraneous rubbish added - its a trading game with a fun and engaging theme.  I would baulk at playing with 5 or more, if you want a good game workout.  With this many, the decisions seem too obvious - its actually TOO easy to manage your hand.  With less people there are less types of beans being farmed and more decisions to make in managing your hand of cards.  That said, playing with 6 or 7 people is still fun and there are not many turn-based games which have effectively zero downtime with 6 people!  Bohnanza also has a problem it shares with Carcassonne - you can actually play this in a 'nasty' way, but its a family gateway game so nastiness is not really the thing to do, even though if its best for your chances.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Winning this game is largely random, but that's just fine - I've had a lot of fun playing it, as has everybody I've introduced to it. The theme is a stroke of genius, for how it lends itself to humorous commentary and for how it makes people skeptical at first only to quickly be converted.

Don't take it too seriously.
Don't play with fewer than 5 players.
Don't buy the Fan Edition, which appears to have been produced by people who want new players to hate Bohnanza.

11-Mar-08: I've now tried out the 2-player Bean duel a handful of times. As expected it's a whole different animal. What I didn't expect is that it is a decent game in its own right, something I'd rate on a par with the likes of Lost Cities.

RATING: 7
This trading game has a lot of fun interaction to offer, especially about the beans! We didn't realize that orchestrating trades with more than one player was outlawed in the rulebook, but the game is so much better with it. When you play Bohnanza, play with the rule that you can trade stuff you get more than once. It has a cute and fun theme and interesting mechanics. If it got over about fifteen minutes quicker it would improve my opinion of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very fun card-based game that is great for groups of 4 or more.  The game incorporates strategy and deal-making between players.  The interactions are the most fun and engaging.  People wheel-and-deal, trying to plant the best and most profitable bean crops.  There are only a limited number of each type of bean and rarity is reflected in the value of a crop.  This is a game that everyone should have in their collection.  Playing time varies, but usually takes about 40 minutes (varies based on how long people debate and argue over deals!).  I love this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A gorgeously illustrated great little game of forward planning and cruel betrayal by ones fellow bean farmers. Simple but surprisingly nuanced and complex. Good fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Bohnanza is usually a pretty easy game to teach and most everyone I know enjoys it.  It is interesting in that there are many different play styles.  Many times I have seen very friendly, willing-to-trade players do very well because of the goodwill they have generated.

This is also a good game to play with my French classes as the negotiation forces conversation.

RATING: 8
A great little card game. Very simple rules though you need to check how it scales with different numbers. Could become a little too analyzed. The artwork is fun and the quick play is certainly a plus. The trading is a little one dimensional when people run low on cards. 
Great hand order mechanic. I really like that aspect.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Played once in a three-player game and it was agony. The rule that says you cannot rearrange your own cards really bugged me. Made me feel like my hands were tied the whole game. The rule that forces you to play the first card in your hand made gameplay seem too mechanical. My turn: I'm forced to play this card that happens to be at the front of my hand. Does anyone want to pay me for this random card I did not work to create, but just drew off the top of the deck? No? Okay, I'm uprooting my field with it, then. Your turn. And repeat. Where are the choices? There is NO sense of self-determination in Bohnanza. And three times through the giant deck seems like twice too many. It lengthens the game for no reason.

If you disliked Bohnanza, you might like [thing=54043][/thing]. Now there's a trading game that's [i]actually fun[/i].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Perhaps it was the groups I played with, but I generally was able to keep a steady flow of cards to my fields, so each turn felt more or less like taking care of some housecleaning and letting the system play itself.  I'd like to try it with some more advanced players and trade options, like futures.

RATING: 6.5
Good mechanics, and a good deal on non-gamer appeal.  Hate playing with people who play too nice -- accepting trades that are advantageous to their opponent but don't do them any good. Some say it's a karma thing, and what goes around comes around. But thems that say that don't win, so I don't buy into the argument. Otherwise, fun cards, fun game, good length, nice mechanics. There's a reason there have been so many subsequent bean games.

RATING: 9
I feel a bit cheeky to rate it after only one play but really, it is a fantastic game mechanic, very easy to pick up and highly involving to play, with lots of interaction between players in the trading phase. Strategy is deeper than you might think, given it is a card game with a lot of luck depending on the draw order.

I imagine people who are good at counting cards can nail this one.

RATING: 6.5
Good, light card game. Both the static card order and the trade mechanisms are pretty unique and creative. Much better with more rather than less people, because the trading is what makes the game!  I've played the two-player variant several times as well, which is still fun but tends to be a lot more random since the trading element of the game is essentially removed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a winner in many ways. Unique mechanics that force you to trade to win - big plus. Most euros that involve trading either don't encourage trading, or do only to a point beyond which trading becomes a liability. Here, you need to trade often and throughout the game in order to win.

Best with 5 players. Decent with four players, but a fifth added in makes it shine. Six players is still fun but tends to be a little bit chaotic, and the sixth player may get shafted on number of turns. Seven is too many - the sixth and seventh players will almost certainly have fewer turns than the other players, and will struggle to keep up. Three is a marginal playing experience. Don't bother with two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Rules have some concepts that are difficult to understand until a hand or two have been played.  
(January 2005)

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My favorite trading game! Bohnanza is a gateway card game, with a "forced planting" mechanic that adds a sense of urgency to harvesting your fields. Unlike a lot of gateway games, this one is built around player interaction. It's light-hearted and friendly enough to play with non-gamers, and easy enough for kids to enjoy. This one kicked Chinatown right off my shelf. I have the expansion for this, but have never played it because, for me, Bohnanza is perfect just as it is.

RATING: 8.5
[b]Purchase/Selling History[/b]: 
Got for Birthday from parents after they bought a copy for themselves and had learned about it/played it through a friend from Australia. '06?

[b]Rating: 8.5[/b]
[i]Design rating[/i]: [b]4.5[/b]
[i]Component rating[/i]: [b]1[/b]
[i]Willingness to play rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b]
[i]Fun rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b]

[b]Players considerations[/b]: 
Sweet spot 4-6 I think, but too many talkative players can make this drag.

[b]My thoughts[/b]:   
So pleasant to play, when everyone is moving quickly enough, warning don't play with more than the recommended amount of players. This is a gem, does work better with more players, but maybe it just makes it more fun, idk.
I didn't like how every time we played this we had too many players and people were slow. This is very cutthroat though and leads up to a great end scoring. I wish others were as cutthroat as I am when I play. I like to add the third bean fields to the deck to make them trade fodder.

RATING: 7
A very intuitive set collection game predicated on trading beans of all things! Easy to teach and plays quick. Uwe is one of my favorite board game designers, and while the theme of this game is something that is similar to other games of his, agriculture being a main sub-theme always, I think there is enough substance to this game without having to make it overly complex like some other people might find Agricola, OeL, or Le Havre. One I plan to pick up and play again. Solid 7. Nothing more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very fun card game that plays well with both smaller and  larger groups. The inability to change card order is the big unique element that takes constant reminders for newer players but is also the basis for trades during the course of the game. Keeping track of sales throughout the game could help with late game plant decisions, but is not necessary to still be competitive. Have a few of the many expansions, but have not played them much.

High Bohn Plus

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[size=12][b]Top 300 or higher board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Bohnanza:[/b][/size]
+ There is high player involvement
+ There is high replayability
+ The game is easy to teach
+ There are decisions to make in order to win the game

[size=12][b]Fixable dislikes in regards to Bohnanza:[/b][/size]
/ I am neutral to the theme. I nonetheless hate the art for the game, which is fixable via a P&P version of the game. 

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Bohnanza:[/b][/size]
- I was not a fan of having to maintain card order as this limits the depth of the game. 
- The game is best at an odd player count - 5 players
- The game drags on for what feels like a filler game
- There are too little decisions to make. The best choice is often obvious. 

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Not willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 8
Bohnanza is a very good game. The one thing that makes it less than the perfect game is actually the artwork, which, while I think is perfect, unfortunately does turn some people off. The trading mechanism is offset by two small rules that make the game tricky (the inability to re-order one's hand and the minor restrictions on harvesting). But this is sufficient to make this game awesome!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Finally managed to play Bohnanza.
It is a strange game and the trading might lead to kingmaking.
I also had one turn more than the other players. Not sure I had any benefit since I didn't manage to trade in the first round. But the person who lost the tiebreaker against me thinks otherwise.
Anyway I am not a fan of tiebreakers.
I do however like how certain bohns become more rare, since they are money.
The draw deck is thinner and the game picks up space.
I rate it a six since there are quicker card games that offer more or the same amount of fun in that timeframe.
And i prefer boardgames

RATING: 7.2
Unique hand management, set collection, and negotiation. Five seems to be the optimal number of players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cool, light game, all about negotiation and full of interaction. It's easy to play, easy to teach and learn. There's no downtime since the main part of every player's turn is trading, which involves everyone. 
With proper people the game can be very entertaining and its depth grows with smarter opponents. 
It plays smoothly and there's no set-up so it's easy to bring out and play even if you only have an hour.
The theme is just funny and easy for anyone to understand.
It's a lot of nice features for a super cheap game that is small enough to fit in a pocket. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Bohnanza is the first in the Bohnanza family of games and has been published in several different editions.

As card games go, this one is quite revolutionary. Perhaps its oddest feature is that you cannot rearrange your hand, as you need to play the cards in the order that you draw them. The cards are colorful depictions of beans in various descriptive poses, and the object is to make coins by planting fields (sets) of these beans and then harvesting them. To help players match their cards up, the game features extensive trading and deal making.

RATING: 8
I like this game a lot! The bean theme is very funny. This is partly due to comical drawings of different kinds of beans. 

The cards must be kept in order you draw them and the card you draw first must be played first. Because of that you'll often need the card you don't have (or want to get rid of one), and one way to get it is negotiating with other players. That causes a lot of laughter around the table. The more people play, more negotiation possibilities arise and that leads to more funny situations and more laughter.
 
But what ruins this game for sure are AP-prone players.

RATING: 6
The theme and art are goofy, but that sets up some really good jokes throughout.  Who can pass up the charm of saying "I'll give you wax for stink?"

What I don't like about the game is that you need at least 6 players for it to really shine.  With less there are just too many beans in the deck for trading to be necessary -- you get a lot of people doing their own thing and just trying to give beans away.  Maybe it'd work better if you pulled even more beans out of the deck.  I'll have to try that.

The two-player version is an admirable attempt at creating something playable, but it's not fun for me.

RATING: 7

I tried it 2-player, won't do that again.

RATING: 8
I still can't find a fitting comment for Bohnanza. It's so dependent on the right group that it dazzles me sometimes. The game itself it's great but the interaction of the players its so closely attached that the 8 is because of the game mechanics. I keep in the level of Cosmic Encounter when it comes to player interaction, but the negotiations become so fierce that sometimes it becomes overwhelming or somewhat chaotic. The chaos is not limited in the game (like in Cosmic Encounter where the balance lies within the interaction of players) so the game goes sometimes unbalanced if the last negotiation becomes beneficial to one player (for example if someone is trying to get an specific card in their last turn and then he/she just trades most of his/her hand to another player). I dunno if we're playing something wrong, but the game seems somewhat "forgiving" if that's the right term...

Edit: We WERE playing the game wrong. We skipped this rule: you can't get rid of a plantation of only 1 card. Also we planted the cards whenever we wanted so it became a lot more forgiving (it WAS the appropriate term). We played it a few times with the correct rules and it became cutthroat and amazing. The rating doesn't go up because I'm still not sure why I don't like some aspects of the game... maybe it's too "balanced" for me. Even when the interaction of players is the most important game, the game always is tightly balanced by numbers and "hidden statistics". Also I've been playing so much that it may affect the rating...
 
(Mostly played with 5-6)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[GAMEID=11] was a game that we were itching for since it looked like a lot of fun with a large group of people (and it certainly looked better than most of the typical party games).  And it worked---we've had a blast bringing this out at several dinner parties.  There's nothing like trying to wheel and deal and get your beans into play.  Since the negotiation aspect is forced onto you since you can't rearrange your cards, everybody gets into it and no one feels left out.  It also appeals to the card counters, since by watching the deck you can get a better grasp on the real values of the beans being dealt.  We've had lots of fun with this game with many different groups of people.

So it was with a little apprehension that we tried the two player game.  How could this even work?  Turns out, the two player rules included in the Rio Grande version work surprisingly well and really keep the flavor of the multiplayer game.  You draw and plant cards like normal.  There's really not much direct trading, but you do have to leave cards for the other player at the end of your turn.  Your opponent can pick up the cards that you've turned in, so it the tension comes from the risk of hurting yourself by keeping cards or helping out your opponent by giving them away.  

In practice, it has that [GAMEID=50] feel---a lightly strategic card game that's easy to play, but still has a decent amount of meat to it.  There's a similar feeling of [i]what cards can I risk leaving for my opponent?[/i]  Since it's ultra-portable, we usually take it with us on trips home to play with friends and family, but it's also a good game to break out while you're stressed out in the airport.  If you have the game, it's worth trying out the two player game at least once.

Session Reports:  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/220519]Newbie Group's First Time[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A must in every collection.  Wonderful interaction for a hugely social game which is accessible for every level of gamer.  The do-not-shuffle rule is inspired and this little touch plus a few other clever ideas pushes the game into classic status.  It is maybe tiresome to stress the details, when it is the big gestures that often grab peoples attention, but the designer could of made obvious simpler choices and had an average workable set collection game.  However, the extra detail in the right places at the right times make it essential and sets it apart. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A nice lighter strategic game. The forced planting/trading and fixed hand elements are cool, and it earns bonus points because it's so accessible. The theming and art are a big help in preventing what could otherwise be a simplistic and bone dry Euro card game from becoming very stale very quickly.

The major flaw is that the gameplay doesn't really develop as a game progresses. Plant, trade, sell is pretty much it, but it's a fun trip.

AP doesn't work here, leave your thinking at the door or you will drag this game down. I would love to one day play this with many more players!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Bohnanza is a classic trading and hand management game from the golden age of German game design. As you would expect from that description, the systems are clean and elegant, player interaction – in the form of the aforementioned trading – is ample, and there is more fun to be had than you would expect from the rules and the quirky bean farming theme.

The ingenious bit is that Bohnanza is a hand management game in which you must play cards in the order you drew them. This simple rule, which has almost never been reused, drives negotiations because trading away cards you can't use will almost always benefit you more than keeping cards away from other players who need them. The cards you flip up randomly each turn (which you must plant if you cannot trade them away) may be the primary spur to action when you are taking your turn, but getting problematic cards out of the way gets the other players to meet you halfway. Without that incentive they would always choose to let you twist in the wind.

Parenthetically, I am grateful to Joe Gola (gola on BGG) for blogging his preference for playing with the German deck instead of the Rio Grande deck, which incorporates the first German expansion. The German deck is smaller, which keeps the game from overstaying it welcome and makes it more likely two or more players will be trying for the same type of bean at the same time. The only downside is that the smaller range of beans makes buying a third field a rather weak play, and false choices are never a good thing. The original Amigo Spiele version is widely available online, although it comes with German rules, of course. If you buy the Rio Grande box, you can revert to the German setup by stripping out the Cocoa, Wax and Coffee Beans. Bohnanza wants to be a 30-45 minute game, not an hour.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
We like this game for the negotiating side of it. The negotiation rule is always a bit tricky to remember, but we really enjoy this game.

RATING: 6
I was skeptical because I haven't played a trading game I've liked yet, but something about Bohnanza makes it work. I think unlike Catan and Compounded that you almost always have something someone wants, and in cases are willing to give away things for free in order to not have to uproot other beans might be a factor. Some nice hand management too in that where your cards come  up in your queue matters. It's also nice that it is a strategic rather than party game that plays up to 6 well. The downside to this game is it runs a little long for a filler, especially if people get into heated haggling. I'm also personally not a fan of the art, though the style kind of fits the theme.

No.  No, I will not help you.  And yes, while you are taking ten minutes on your turn, I will be chatting about non game-related topics.  Finally, when things don't go your way, no pouting, boys.  

I'm pretty much always up for Bohnanza with the ladies. The artwork is fun.  The game play is very simple.  Yet, it requires forethought, some concentration, and to a certain degree, calculation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I never expected to like a game about growing beans so much, but it is really a trading and negotiating game, a genre I love.  Cutting deals makes your bean growing run more smoothly and smoothly means more beans and more profit.  The fixed order of your cards in hand is a brilliant mechanic, if difficult to keep straight for new players, and the dangers of having to plant the wrong kind of bean (throwing off your tempo and thus your earning) should keep the table lively with chatter.  There is some luck of course, as the turn of the beans to trade has a large effect, but a good wheeler-dealer will usually find himself with a nice pile of gold at the end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Maybe I just haven't played with the right people, but in my experience, this game is almost too friendly.  I find myself constantly making good trades, giving cards away, getting cards I need.  Rarely is there a situation where I'm really competing for a card I want.  And even when there is, and I lose the negotiation, it's often likely that another one of those cards will be coming around soon.  It's okay.  The artwork is cute.  It's not un-fun... just a little slack.

Update 9/1/14 -- Have played a good deal more since last comment; a better game than I first thought.  Play is still pretty leisurely, but there's a pleasantly mercenary quality to it at its best.  And it's a slightly mercenary game that everyone will agree to play.  Nice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Games that consist entirely of cards with cute illustrations and numbers on them usually send me running in the opposite direction. Add all the theme you like, & a War or Rummy variation will always still be instantly identifiable as such. But this game is genuinely different - the card order and trading mechanic give it an utterly unique feel and allow for lots of tight, tricky tactical decision-making. This is truly ingenious use of absolutely minimal resources.

RATING: 7
An early Uwe Rosenberg design where you are planting and harvesting beans.  The interesting mechanic is that you cannot change the order of your cards and you must plant at least your first card every turn.  This often results in trying to get rid of cards that would force you to harvest.  There is a lot of player interaction and trading.  An excellent family game and a lot of fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Flimsy cardstock, but a good light game with plenty of interaction. Works well with a bigger (5-6) group, which is rare.

This is one of my favourite games. So much of the game depends on negotiation, and I love that good play often demands making lopsided trades in order to ensure long-term profitability (something that's much less common in games such as Catan). People who don't like negotiation will hate this, but I love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
([url=www.boardgamebliss.com]Boardgamebliss.com[/url], 2015-01-13)

Bohnanza is a fine card game that will force all players to trade, sometimes take bad trades to keep their bean fields a little longer. The game is fun but probably a bit too long for what it is.

(Traded for [thing=175458][/thing] in [geeklist=203468][/geeklist], 2016-01-25)

RATING: 8
Solid card game with fast play and great conversations to take out of context. Play lightheartedly and don't try to haggle trades too much and this will play fast and friendly. If you try to play too competitively this slows down the game and makes this a non-interesting game.  Do your best to leave behind a single Cocoa Bean in the first round, it's always fun to be passing around a useless bean later in the game.

RATING: 8.5
Played two player... first game went down to the "who had the most cards in hand" tiebreaker.  Fun!  However, I suspect my rating would change if I ever get to play it with more than two, as the negotiation aspect would come alive.

UPDATE:  Played with five, and it is a very different game.  It moved quickly, and the trading/negotiation aspect was a hoot.  Increased rating - call it a 7 for 2 players, and a 9 for more.

UPDATE:  Played with seven.  It felt like there was no downtime, as the wheeling and dealing was constant.  Some "tricks" became apparent - trading for future donations, trading same card for same card to get an out of turn plant, etc.  I ran Green and Chili to 4GP's each right out of the gate, and went on to win with 11GP.

Not too difficult to learn, but exciting to play. The twoplayer mode is not as good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I used to like this a lot, but found out one day that I'd always played it wrong: I thought that only the player whose turn it was could make gifts to the other players, not vice versa, and I also thought that he could only add cards from his hands to a deal, not make deals with cards from the hand alone. For me, the open-ended trading in the actual rules (which were eventually noted to me) turned an enjoyable quick trading game into a very long borefest that was more arbitrary to boot. With my house rules, I'd still rate it as a solid 7, without them, it's currently my least favorite game in our collection.
Played 20+ times with the wrong rules and 3 times with the correct ones.

RATING: 6
I enjoy negotiation games as a concept, but they often tend towards chaos.  This one really walks that knife-edge.  It doesn't fall completely into a nasty mess as "I'm the Boss" does, but with so many people there's so much information flying around to really make a decision.  I too often find myself picking whatever option happens to be convenient judge to make the incoherent information stop.  I think Santiago and Bootleggers have more interesting negotiation schemes and a much more controlled setting.

RATING: 6
A simple card game that when played with the right crowd can be brilliant. The main gameplay mechanic that shines with a good group is the whole trading system. If you have a highly interactive group then this is going to be time well spent.

Collect beans, plant them, rip up fields to sell, and make sure you are getting the most from your sold fields! A fun game with lots of fun folks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very clever trading game.  You are by default forced into horrible situations which you must get out of, often by trades that help other players.  Many layers of analysis are possible, but in the end it is just a fun game.  A fantastic game to close the evening -- after a serious brainburner like 1825, el grande, etc., the comparatively gentle Bohnanza is a relief.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Don't mess with bean farmers. Its a cutthroat world in bean farming, but a lucrative one. Be patient enough in cultivating your beans and you will reap the gold; be too greedy and you may be go through your crops faster than locusts, and all at a loss! Bohnanza is a trading game with a hint of strategizing in planning ahead. So dont be fooled by how simple and impersonal bean planting may sound. Players are always on the lookout for a quick buck and a good deal whenever trades hit the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A card collection game, where you trade beans to get a set of 2-10 and sell to gain coins. After depleting the deck 3x the most coins win. The fun comes from the free for all trading where you try to convince the other players your deal is the best. 

Purchased: Late Summer 2016 (Titan)

RATING: 9
If you have Rio Grande Version, take out the Cocoa, Wax, and Coffee Beans unless you want to use the included expansion. I didn't know this was an expansion until just recently.   Taking them out reduces the game length and makes the game way more fun for fewer players; especially for those new to the game. If you have more than 5, use the expansion. Very fun game once you understand the counter-intuitive mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I find that the two player variant rules for this game make the game even more enjoyable than playing with 3-4. Rather than the game rely on a lot cross table interaction between players, in the two player variant, players choose from a communal selection of beans, which don't have to be planted if you don't want to, but they become more valuable as they stack up. Turns this game more euro due to the indirect player interaction, but it makes gameplay more enjoyable as far as i'm concerned, and less stressful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

We've shown many of our friends this game since we bought it.  With modification it even plays well with only 2 players too.

In short, one of our favorites.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Bohnanza is a set collection game.  In it you are trying to plant various types of beans in your gardens.  By "plant" I mean place cards with different bean drawings out on the table in front of you.

The game was mildly amusing.  The cards were of average quality.  Overall it was pretty forgetful though.  Hence, I have nothing else to say about it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is pretty much a pure trading game. If you like a game where your success hinges on how well you can convince other players to make trades, you'll love it.

If you're like me, and you dislike most trading games, you won't. My issue with trading games, be it this or Catan, isn't just the arbitrariness of some of the trades and the impact that can have on the game, but it's the length. All the haggling can cause games like this to drag interminably. This is an extremely light game, and it takes a full hour to play, which to me is too long. Particularly when most of the game is people saying 'a green bean for a chili bean', 'a stink bean for a red bean', 'a wax bean for a soy bean', over and over and over again until you want to scream.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My friends seem to like this game a lot.  I thought the first couple play-throughs were fun but I don't really like this game mechanically.  While the idea of having your hand work as a queue adds an interesting element to the game, it also goes against every other card game where people naturally sort their hand without thinking about it.  

I also feel that the 3rd bean field is too cheap.  I think it would be better if it started costing 6 and then each field after that would cost one less.  As it stands, the 3rd bean field actually reduces the amount of player interaction as reduces the chance that you will be forced to plant over something you want.

The game is far from bad I guess I just wish there was more to it then just the bean trading.  I would play it again but I doubt it will ever grow on me enough to make it into my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Everybody we have shared this game with has gone out and bought their own copy! Highly interactive, light-hearted, trading/speculating game. Very attractive artwork, and easy to follow rules. My wife and I got my father- and mother-in-law to play this game one night while on vacation. Our folks demanded we play again... and again... and again. We were there for a week and concluded each evening with a game of Bohnanza. It was a LOT of fun for all, and some pretty interesting propositions came up. For instance, my father-in-law offered to babysit our  children for a year in exchange for a cocoa bean! Too bad we didn't have any kids at the time :)

RATING: 8
A great trading game that excels by forcing players to profit through trade as much as possible during their opponents' turns. A good bargainer who can recognize the mutual benefit from a trade usually wins. Getting rid of cards that will hurt you is important, and knowing when and who to donate or trade them to is the name of the game. People who sit back and try to make things happen only during their own turn tend to lose. This is a fun game, and a loud one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
UPDATE: Acquired the Sissi!-version that I have high hopes for. I'll keep it as a separate entry (under its own name).

A game I've played too much. It holds little interest as the same pattern unfolds each time I play. Probably because of playing in the same group, also, the valuations that players have to make are too similar and if not obvious not that challenging either.

I've purchased the Ladybohn expansion to help offset this, and I intend to play it with that in the future to see if it helps.

However, it is a very enjoyable game, bartering with (or just badgering) your fellow players so you end up the richest bean farmer of all. The moment of insight when people realize you can win without getting your "value" on each and every trade - as long as you manage to make so many more trades than your opponents. The metagame aspect (I trade my partner, friend, wife etc) I guess I could do without, but bah, it's minor at worst. Also, it sometimes goes a bit long, especially with 5 or more but bah.

It has a very nice charm to it, and works with mixed groups of children and adults rather well, the whole haggle and barter bit is something most people can get into - and I play for those devious moments where you can stoneface someone into accepting a poor trade, lest they lose that stack they have the perfect hand for. Also, the game doesn't let anyone fall too far behind, as the leading players will be quick to cut their prices in order to keep their closest opposition from getting a favourable deal.

A good game! Hoping to blow some life into it with the Ladybohn expansion. Haven't come across other player driven / negotiation games at this level of complexity and length (though I know about Chinatown which kinda fits)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great, fun, wacky game for all ages.  Very casual.  Very easy for newbies.  Light and fluffy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Good game. I enjoyed it quite a bit ... and for some reason rated it a 5. Must've been smoking crack.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Trade your beans for others beans to plant in your fields. Harvest the fields to get points, the more beans when harvested, the more points.

Played as: 4,6,7,8 player

Pros: Excellent player interaction and themed in a way that some non-gamer could look at it and think 'That looks simple enough, I'll play.' My favorite part is how it's been designed to force trading, and stinginess rarely gets you anywhere. Can work just as well with regular gamers, especially with bigger numbers (5+).

Cons: Typical of trading games, it can drag on and sometimes even turn into bitter feelings. Oh, and that's all this is-- trading / negotiation. Even when the game doesn't drag on un-necessarily, it still feels a little like it over stays its welcome for being such a simple fun game.

Other: People have said this game can vary depending on the group it's being played with and now after playing with a few different groups, I can firmly back that statement. I prefer the game with 6-7 players as cards get dealt out faster and there always seems to be a market for something somewhere.  That creates a faster play since people don't need to constantly try to find something that's just not there for them.

Best Use: A light way to maximize player interaction. More people is better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pretty interesting card game of hand management, set collection and trading. You are planting beans in your crops, trying to grow them so you can sell them for money, the trick is that the cards in your hand cannot be moved around, so you need to find ways to get rid of bean types you aren't collecting, hopefully by trading with another player who has the types you have. The crux is to know when to sow some goodwill with another player and when to push to get a better deal. Works well with different number of players, but I prefer it with three.

RATING: 8
This is the only trading game I've played that I felt has worked well with non-gamers. To do this, a game has to get non-gamers involved AND it has to keep the non-gamers from blowing the game up with bad trades. Non-gamers seem to get valuation in Bohnanza fairly well. It's a fun game even if you don't win. And the theme is quite humorous. The game also earns an extra ratings point from me because I enjoy the 2P variant quite nicely. It's almost like 2 games in one box.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We play it often because it's quick to teach and even new players will often get the hang of it half way through their first game.  The fact that it can be played well with 3-7 players means we'll often suggest it, although we've found 4-5 works best.  There's definitely skill in the game, but it's quite possible for someone to win the first time they play.  A light game that's great value for money.

RATING: 8
This is one of my better half and my favorite games to pla with each other. You can play it with 2-7 players, but the 2 player game is very different than the 3+ player game. The main game (3+ player) is based off of trading, planting, and harvesting beans to acquire gold. It's a great social game (as you need to trade with other players to get the beans that you want). The rules aren't too complicated, so it's not hard to teach others.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Outstanding game with the right group.  The trade mechanics with other players, an absolute necessity for victory, is really what makes this game shine.  You can play however you want: nice-guy, aggressive, cutthroat, etc.  Don't burn yourself however.  If you alienate players too much, you'll lessen your chances of making trades.  

Many hours were spent playing this game with a large group around the dining room table late into the night.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
First impression: a game of 10 rating. Great game expresience, easy to teach even to non-gamers, great flow. Imagined that I would allways love this game.

After app. 50 plays I've changed my mind completely. The game rely a lot on the relations of the gamers. I.e. if you play with for example a couple in love you are almost doomed to lose the game, or at least to get less favourable trades.

It's still a great game though... and great to bring to parties with non-gamers/unexperienced gamers, but I change my rating to 6.8

[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Unconventional, yet addictive card trading game
* Mechanics are deceptively simple, yet planning, strategy and cunning are required

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played once with a group of six.  The game focuses on collecting cards (beans) of the same type by either trading cards in your hand with other players or drawing cards.  The more cards of the same type you collect, the more points you get.  Cards in your hand are in a fixed order, and you are forced to play cards from your hand each turn; thus, strategizing which cards to take, hold, and trade can be complex.  This is also not a trick-taking game, which is nice.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Planting and harvesting fields of beans--a very amusing way to pass some time! One of the few games we play where little attention is paid to who might be winning at any given moment. It works better that way I think.

One of the beauties of this design is that, unlike some trading games, it's immediately very clear why trading is essential (to improve the order of the cards in your hand if nothing else), compelling you to actually [i]want[/i] to make trades on a regular basis. The dual function of the cards as both beans and money, which results in a gradually shrinking deck, is ingenious.

We mostly play with three players, which works just fine. Whether to start a 3rd field is always a tough decision. Nicknames for the beans (hippy, smelly, puky, etc.) are a must. Have the Erweiterungs-Set expansion but rarely use it. [41 plays]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Received in mathtrade 1/12/09.

A fantastic first play - tons of ineraction, and even a little tension!

Edit 4/6/09: What can I say - this game holds up. It's always entertaining, it is easy enough to teach to non-gamers (who universally note they enjoy it and would play it again), it has enough strategy and negotiation that it can be played by serious gamers (in which case it's massively cut-throat), and it finishes quickly. Plus it's portable in a way Dominion or RFTG is not. I would call this the ultimate toolbox game - fit for all types of players and gaming occasions, easily inserted into a space of time after a family dinner, or between heavier gaming with the guys.

Plus, the beans make me laugh.

----------------------

This game almost always gets played in a family or light-gamer enviroment, NOT in a cut-throat environment, and I find it less and less tolerable an experience in that context. I think the magic spot in this game is if you are all playing like mean bastards fighting over every bean and coin. If not, it is just another stupid card game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Negotiation games such as this one are not so much fun for people like me who aren't quick, persuasive talkers. For everyone else, it's (apparently) a hoot. 

Everybody's talking at the same time, trying to convince the active player that the deal they're offering is the sweetest. I'm not a fast talker, and I don't like talking over people, so my voice just gets lost in the noise, and my score goes right along with it. This is also why I will never play Chinatown again.

I had a copy of Bohnanza years ago, but I soon realized that I was terrible at it and had never really enjoyed my plays of it. So I gave it away. 

Then I realized that, in our group, Bohnanza is a game that tends to be suggested when we've got like 7 people and we're waiting for an 8th person to arrive before breaking into smaller groups, and we've got 15 minutes to kill. Many of the other games that generally fill that role in our group are games that I absolutely despise, such as One Night Ultimate Werewolf. For as bad as I am at negotiation, I'm an order of magnitude worse at social deduction and lying, and so naturally I enjoy those types of games correspondingly less. So much so that games like ONUW make playing Bohnanza feel like heaven. So I reacquired a copy of Bohnanza and now I just keep it around as a less painful alternative for when we've got 15 minutes to kill.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Here is a trading-based family card game that you want to play when you have 5 players.  The "do not reorder the cards in your hand" & "forced plant" mechanisms work surprisingly well to incentivize generous trading. The rules do not feel awkward or uncomfortable. They make players desperate to get crap out of their hands while eagerly hunting the cards needed to complete sets. This game feels simple, deep, silly and elegant; it gets the table laughing, haggling and having fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A really innovative card game that is approaching 20 years old and still going strong.

The players are Bean Farmers and need to plant, harvest and trade their way to a gold haul bigger than anyone elses. 

The catch here is that the players must hold their cards in a set order that cannot be altered and beans must be planted in a set order too. But fields are limited and a single field can only hold 1 type of bean at a time. 

So the players must negotiate and trade away unwanted beans to try and develop well established fields in order to earn a good gold total at harvest time. 

This is a great card game and a good social experience in its own right. It was one of the earliest designer games to accommodate up to 7 players but I prefer 3-5 players. 

It also plays with 2 but the rules are modified somewhat to offer a slightly different experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is our preferred party game, gets pulled out a lot with large groups and new friends. Great to take travelling (small and easy to get players). Good duration and often gets a played a couple of times in a row.

Always good for a laugh or two. Very funny watching couples trading in Bohnanza......

Plays well with 2.

RATING: 6.5
Для казуалов — одна из лучших игр Она совершенно не напрягает мозги: здесь нужно только меняться, выпрашивать и раздаривать карты. Ожидания своего хода нет, т.к. выклянчивать и сбывать карты нужно постоянно не только в свой но и во все чужие ходы (к сожалению, не до всех это сразу доходит). Правда, сильно напрягает правило неперемещения карт в руке: трудно следить за игроками постоянно вынимающими карты из середины руки при предложении об обмене (особенно это касается новичков, а ведь как раз для них предназначена эта игра).
