This is light trading game where you try to broker deals to get the cards you want.  It's very social and let's you see your friends at their wheedling best.

RATING: 5
I can see why this game is considered a classic for some people, but I think the length of the game holds it back considerably. For a game that is just a Rummy variant with some trading and negotiation, this should be a 30-minute game, tops. The 45-minute time on the side of the box is pretty accurate, unfortunately, and I think Bohnanza suffers because of it. If I could get this game played in 20-30 minutes, this would probably stay in my collection, as I haven't played too many games that involve trading that I actually enjoy. There are just too many other better games out there at this point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best game I have played for 'forcing' player interaction. The need to trade and donate in this game is very well implemented. The cartoon like cards make the whole thing fun, but whilst there is a smidge of luck, there is enough in the negotiation and tactical play to make this a good all round game for casual and hardcore gamers alike. we use this as an introducer a lot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Will rate with more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Bohnanza is a great little trading game. It strikes me as comparable to settlers yet it's even more basic in that it's pretty much pure trading and negotiating to get the best deals possible to score the most points you can. In Settlers there is probably a bit more options and arguably a bit more luck as well as your fate due to the dice is also a factor.

Whether this game will hold up to many many repeat plays is yet to be seen but after limited play I can certainly say this is a game I will like to see on the table more often. I can't say I'm all that excited to try the 2 player variant as I don't really anticipate much excitement with just 2 players but I'll of course reserve my judgment and rating with 2 until we get to try it.

As far as multiplayer though... the game has a nice flow without too much downtime. It's always interesting to see what your opponents get with their 2 upcards and how quickly you can bid to get the card you want while serving the active player up a deal they can't resist. :) 

As they say... you scratch my back... I'll scratch yours. This is never more true than here where it's always beneficial to be in the thick of the trading action as often as you can to try and build up as many good runs of cards as you can even if it means helping others. A bit of social networking is at work here as well. If you appear helpful and generous fairly often by donating reasonably frequently... you will often receive reciprocal help from those you've helped. If you are too stingy and shrewd with your dealings... you will sometimes get screwed over when you can least afford it. That's the rub of a trading/negotiating game such as this.      

This one has room to grow with me yet on the upside and I'd especially like to play this with the full complement of 7 players as I suspect it would be a really fun social event with the right players. As many have said, this type of game is either a big hit or a flop depending on how energetic and vocal your group is. I can see this game being pretty close to dead boring and vice versa this can be almost a riot of fun just depending on which types of personalities dominate your gaming circle.

8.5 rating for now with potential to climb slightly and I'd say Bohnanza has a fairly low chance of dropping under an 8 for me as this type of high interaction, low downtime game is one that's pretty easy to get to the table and is popular with those I play with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Bohnanza is one of my favorite trading games right now and can be played with groups of variable sizes with multiple different strategies.

The great thing about this trading game is that most of the trades that are proposed are mutually beneficial and rarely does one party leave feeling like they got the short end of the stick.  However, that doesn't mean that you can't screw over your opponents if your heart is really set on it.

I would highly recommend adding this game to your collection.

RATING: 7.2
15+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bohnanza is all about player interaction, and as such you are engaged in every player's turn.  This makes an otherwise fairly simple game much more enjoyable than it might otherwise be.  The prohibition against reordering your hand is a clever and unique mechanic, and the distribution of beans creates good balance and strategy.

It is Bohnanza's greatest strength that is also its weakness.  A group of aggressive, loud players can drown out a quieter, more timid player, and that player will not do as well and probably won't enjoy themselves as much.  Similarly, a stubborn player who refuses to make otherwise good trades can unfairly hurt a few players, depending on how the cards come up.  All in all, Bohnanza is a fun, engaging game that makes a good warm up or cool down game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It took me ages to get over the goofiness of the illustrations, but I'm glad I took the plunge. Bohnanza is now one of my all-time favourite card games – mechanically simple, but in a non-constricting way. Variety can be added with a number of expansions that build on the base "economy engine" gameplay in surprising ways.

I'd rate it a nine if Al Cabohne weren't even better.

RATING: 7
One of the best party games/ filler/ gateway game available. Lots of fun, great social time too. Card game based on trading different types of beans to earn a payoff. Sure there is luck involved but his highly mitigated by the trading aspect once players know what's going on ;) 

House rule: you can't trade a bean for exactly the same type of bean (e.g. wax for wax) otherwise the game would be broken!

Maybe this would be better after a lot of time passed but I think there are probably better ways to do a trading/negotiation game (I prefer Catan to this).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[Amigo edition] Small box Amigo edition is much better than huge Rio Grande edition. In Rio Grande edition, they not only add expansion cards (4s, 22s and 24s) but also changed the rules according to the number of players. 

For me, Bohnanza is much much better with just using 6-20 (104 cards) and played by 3-5 players. Then it is a very nice friendly trading game that last about 20-30 minutes. 

I played Bohnanza too many times before BGG, but it is still nice to play it once in a while. Truely, Rosenberg's masterpiece.

I got tired of begging for beans about halfway through the game. Another game that is a mystery to me regarding its great popularity (also see Trans America). A second playing has confirmed my dislike of this game. I've also come to the realization that a game that relies heavily on negotiation will almost always be one I don't care for. I've avoided sales my entire professional life and I have no desire for it to infiltrate my game playing. I hate trying to convince people to do things and so I'm at a huge disadvantage in these types of games - I prefer to let my brain, not my mouth, do the gaming.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Far more superior than other card games in the same genre (eg. No Thanks, Fairy Tale, Escalation!, etc.) due to the increased amount of player interaction.

There is a very important rule missing from the English edition:

The active player can offer to trade only 1 card from their hand.

This rule improves gameplay considerably and I would only ever be willing to play the game with it. My rating is also based on playing the game with this rule.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Bohnanza is a classic trading game that can be taught easily, accommodates a wide range of players, and keeps everyone involved during the game. We have owned three or four copies, between wearing out decks and giving them away to friends.

The Bohnaparte expansion is an interesting idea, turning the base game into an economic engine that drives your conquest over different types of territory. Not something I recommend for most people as it's more complex, slower to play, more aggressive, and has a relatively high amount of luck in battle resolution.

Expansions owned:
* Bohnaparte (2003)

RATING: 8
What a strange game! Bohnanza forces players to fight the habit of sorting the cards in your hand as part of the game's main mechanic.

An excellent trading game, but may be hard for introverts to succeed as trades are self-motivated and not pre-structured for the player.

Although Bohnanza appears to be a just a filler, this "bean game" can take over an hour to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Bohnanza is a trading game where you try and plant bean fields of the same type so that you can harvest them for 1-4 coins.  The more rare the bean is in the deck, the less of them you need before they can be harvested for the maximum 4 coins.  I consider Bohnanza a party game because it seems to be good for non-gamers, and the trading aspect of the game really promotes everyone talking.

The game tends to run a bit long and it gets boring for someone that has played it a ton (me), but it still is a go-to game for me when we have non-gamers over that want to sit, drink, and talk around a table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3.5
Lacked the crucial mechanic to get it back on our gaming table time after time. Is it just me, or is the whole point of having a 'hand of cards' in any game the advantage to play them at will, not keep them strictly ordered and close to your chest? It's difficult to see the point in trading when there is no personal benefit.

Best with as many as possible - not great for two, three or even four. Easily ruined by the wrong sort of people, and by 'the wrong sort of people' I probably mean 'me'. Not unhappy to see the back of it.

[i]Sold on eBay[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have never not had a good time playing "the bean game". It always manages to be fun and memorable. It plays fairly quickly, has light strategy elements and heavy player interaction. It gets everyone involved. Even people who 'hate board games' ask me to play this one often.

It can be difficult to get people interested at first though. "How about we play a game about bean farming!" does not go over all that well. But it teaches quickly and is fun from turn #1, so the naysayers are silenced early on. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
[b]Bohnanza[/b] was sold via auction 4/20/15
Received in a math trade 4/14/14.

[i]- Great gateway/family game, especially if you are interested in a game that focuses on trading.
- Encourages trading every turn [i](it is very rare for someone to keep both cards they flip, usually at least one gets traded).[/i]
- Best mechanic in the game [i](which also helps drive trading)[/i] is not being able to rearrange your hand, ever.
- Very easy to teach/learn.
- I like the cartoony artwork and the card quality is excellent.[/i]

RATING: 7.1

As a 2-player game it is wonderful, but with more players it is amazingly fun! With more players the selling and trading of beans is outstanding! The trading is not cut throat...instead it is wild and unpredictable at times, to every ones benefit it seems! This may become one of my favorite party games! Buy a bean farm, plant more beans in your field, build a 3rd farm to plant even more beans, then sell, sell, sell! So good!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The idea of having not only a hand of cards, but a hand-in-order works brilliantly here. It introduces moments not always present in trading games, where you actively DO NOT WANT specific cards and will really work to get rid of them, but not because they are inherently bad cards. Clever.

RATING: 7.5
挺嘴砲的遊戲
規則:
*2人 -4,6號豆，只能自己回合賣豆，買田的錢移出遊戲，牌庫第一次用完就結束，1.種植或丟棄對手剩的豆，2.種完1~2張豆後可棄一張牌，3.抽三張到桌上，如果棄牌頂牌一樣就跌到牌面上直到棄牌頂牌不一樣，想種的就種，不想種的送給對手4.補兩張手牌
*3人-4號 起始三條田(不能再買)，牌庫用完第二次結束
*4-5人 -24號豆
*6-7人 -4,6號豆，起始3張，下一位4張，在來五張，其它六張，補牌時抽四張，豆子田兩枚金幣
*起始兩田，第三田三枚金幣，起始五張手牌，順序不能改變
1.至少種一豆，可種兩張，都要照順序，如過沒空田就要強制賣掉，要先賣兩張以上的田
2.抽兩張到牌面，開始交易或捐贈，只能跟主動玩家作，捐贈可不收，交易可拿牌面或手牌跟其他玩家手牌交易，交易過的牌不能再交易
3.種交易或捐贈的豆規則同1賣豆要全賣，金幣為將該豆翻面使用，其它豆放在棄牌推
4.補充3張牌
*第三次牌抽完就結束，補牌時抽玩直接結束遊戲
*金幣平手比手牌

RATING: 7
I couldn't believe the same guy who did those miserable farming games also did this fun party game of negotiation. Bohnanza requires constant engagement with your fellow bean-planters and a few stabs at strategy while Agricola/Caverna makes you put the blinders on and worry about developing your own farm, regardless of what anyone else is doing. Any game where everyone is engaged throughout the entire game, I think is a winner. It's what separates just plain good games to fantastic, classic games. Love the game.

RATING: 8
As card games go, this is fairly special. The trades, counter-trades and general whining about not trading with the winner brings the table to life. The key rule is not allowing people to shift cards in their hand, creating a need to trade so you're not forced to harvest your melds before they're big enough to score well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game with a different take for card games (at least, it was for me).  Adds nice variety to a day/night of gaming without too much complexity, but still has interesting choices to make.  A bit of a "card counter" game since tracking what's been played will definitely improve the decisions you make as the game progresses, but with a friendly group that's not a huge issue.

The trading aspects are really where this one lives and breathes, so if that's not a mechanic you like, there's little point in playing.  Smart trading or donations (which are allowed) will make and break your game, and victory is going to go the person that does well here.  A bit of luck with the distribution of the cards, but not so much that you'll be cursing the game regularly.  Plus, the trading helps you offset random bad stuff while taking advantage of random good stuff.

Fun, fast, and with sufficient depth to be interesting without causing headaches.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
12/11/10 - After sitting on my shelf for a month, I finally got my friends to play this game. The four of us enjoyed the game but later I discovered we played it wrong. I thought when you donated a card the player had to keep it.

1/15/11 - This game is a blast. I played a six player game with couples. When a significant other wouldn't trade with their spouse.....Woo boy! Look out! Who knew a game about bean farming could be so much fun.

Draw 3 cards instead of 2 for the trade round. Discard 1 after trades.

RATING: 9
Simply the best light negotiation game out there.  There's really never a dull moment in this game, though the flow of the game can be somewhat group-dependent.  Works very well even with non-gamers, and scales very well up to 7 players.  There are a few niggling rules that are difficult for new players to remember (not reordering your hand, not digging up 1-fields), but as long as you make a note of it during teaching you should be fine.

(5+ plays)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not being able to adjust your hand and being forced to plant beans makes this game stand out from all the other negotiation games. You start to make shitty deals because you HAVE to get rid of the beans unless you're going to plant them yourself. I like how you run through the deck 3 times and the deck gets smaller and smaller each time. What looks like a game that would take hours to get through a 3rd time, the deck is a fraction of what it was before. What a great game.

If you hate negotiation, you may still like this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Got a 5-player group and looking for a medium-length card game? Bohnanza is a classic, as it can offer a game experience varying from light family-friendly discussions ("[i]Sure, I'll give you a red bean for a soy bean[/i]) to cutthroat negotiations ("[i][b]That's[/b] what you offer for my Garden bean? There are just 6 in the whole game![/i]"). Either way, it's a game that each group should play at least once. Works pretty well to break the ice, too!

RATING: 6
Fun card game, trying to get melds of different types of beans (11 varieties, different # of cards for each), and clever that you can only plant the bean(s) that are the first card(s) in your hand - there's no rearranging your cards.  This game should appeal to those who love cards.  The rules aren't as complicated as they seem -- just start playing and the rules should be understand pretty well after one game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Uwe Rosenberg's famous game of bean-farming.  This is basically a matching-collecting game, where you want to "sow" bean cards in your "fields", matching as many of a kind as possible to score coins.  But the game rules force you to regularly plant new beans, so you can wind up being forced to harvest before you're ready if you're not careful.  Suitable for families with kids, the art of the different kinds of beans is colorful and often quite funny, although some of the jokes require the understanding of a German pun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rate a game with it's peers - this is no Puerto Rico but is a fantastc trading game all on it's own.  Guaranteed interaction and a very good start to a games evening

RATING: 7
Easy to learn and play, but hard to keep friends throughout the whole game.  As a game it is a strong 8 (good for a card game), but as practice for running for office, it would be a 10.  Bean trading where you can't change cards around in your hand... makes for some interesting trades where players have to decide if losing a lot of cards someone else might need is worth keeping themselves from having to play them.  The element of having cards that are good for one person but bad for someone else is quite intriguing.

RATING: 8

It's something anyone can understand, and doesn't take a long time.  The comic artwork is fun, and the mechanics are great. The strategy lies not only in what you're dealt, but in how you deal with others. You have to barter and make allies and enemies in order to further your own beany bidding.

RATING: 5
I've played this a few times and I'm left wondering why it is highly regarded. I think I can put it down to the fact the game is attitude dependant to make it enjoyable. I found it a little mechanically repetitive, and the trading can be a little long winded. It may benefit from once around trading like Res Publica. But Bohnanza has a bitter pill to swallow: if no one wants to trade for the two middle cards that you don't want to plant, you're forced to reap at a low rate. I guess that is where part of the fun lies for some. I like the frustrating "fixed hand,play from front" rule and the conversion of beans to money mechanic (utilised better in Klunker).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great gateway game.  Easy to teach.  Every group I've played with thus far has loved it.  While there's a lot of luck, there's actually a surprising amount of depth and strategy there as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
-

An over-rated card game involving planting bean fields, bean trading, and negotiation. I didn't have a good impression of it after the first play, and repeated play confirmed my initial impression. This is primarily because I don't particularly care for trading/negotiation games. The game, like Settlers of Catan, is very susceptible to meta gaming during card trading. Another negative is the "must keep your cards in the same order" which is somewhat counter intuitive and is far from an elegant core mechanics, but that's what makes this game possible. If you like trading and negotiations, you will probably like this game.

-

RATING: 9
I don't play this game anywhere near as much as I used to but the 9 rating still holds.

Another must have for any gaming collection. 
And considering the price point, this game cannot be beat.   

Bonus - the art is really fun as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
What went on here? Who selected the colors? (Dark blue and black along with a pale yellow on a white background.) Even those that are not colorblind had trouble distinguishing the colors.

The game is played in two phases. The first phase players roll to accumulate as many brains as possible. In the second phase, players attempt to roll the colors of their opponents in order to deprive them of brains.  It is a game of player elimination that is based solely on die rolls. There are virtually no decisions to make - just roll and roll and roll again. 

Knizia tends to run hot and cold...this game is well below freezing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
Rating has fallen a bit after appx. 20 plays of this. It is a good card game with a very unique mechanic and quite a bit of negotiation/bartering. I will always want to play this with casual gamers and will even use this as a gateway game for brand new gamers. The hand mechanic (not changing the order of the cards and having them cycle through your hand) is unique enough to offer something different to newbies and the bartering keeps everyone involved. Almost everyone I have introduced it to wants to play again right away. Positives: Very unique mechanic for a card game, good gateway game, very social game. Negatives: Not enough meat for my gaming group, falls flat as a filler for heavier gamers (also too long for filler status).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not sure about the game, rating might go up if/when we replay.

RATING: 8.5
This is an amazingly fun little game, where 80% of the game is about your capacity to influence others, and to find creative ways out of a seemingly deadlocks.  It's a game about talking, providing perspective and building trading relationships... at high speed.

However, because it relies so heavily on social interaction around the table, beware of picking the right people to play it with: there's nothing more depressing than a round of bohnanza with players that are not engaging in negotiations.

RATING: 8
Primarily a trading game. The restrictive hand management mechanic generates an incentive for trading. Keeping the "active" player involved in the trade keeps the game from being too chaotic. Downtime in minimized since you need to be aware of what is being traded when it not your turn.

Best played in light quick rounds - if you try to analyze and optimize each trade - you'll suck the enjoyment right out.

RATING: 7.5
The central mechanism or limiting factor for this game is that the players can only play cards from their hands in the order they are dealt, making trades necessary. Without this central conceit, there would be no game. With it, this is a marvelous gateway game. Just keep reminding new players not to rearrange their cards!

RATING: 8

Overall this is just a fun game that I suspect will get tons of plays with us in 2017.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
= 2017-11-06 - R:8

Increasing my rating from 6.5 to 8. I rated the game as a 2 player game and that's completely unfair. The game never should have claimed to work for 2. That said, if you DO want to play 2 player Bohnanza, Bohnanza: the Duel is out now and it works wonderfully. Highly recommended.

I've played Bohnanza a few more times with mixed groups of gamer/non-gamer friends and it's always a blast. This and Codenames are the two games I find myself pulling out more often than anything else when friends are over and we want to still socialize while playing.

= 2012-10-07 - R:6.5

We're going to give the 2p version a shot and hope it can compete with Battle Line for time at our table.

UPDATE: The Bean Duel is boring. Fortunately, we have tons of excellent two player card games now so we probably won't try to force this one to work any more. Still not giving this one a rating until we've played it 3+ player at least one more time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A game non-gamers like. It is incredibly frustrating to play with non gamers  however as one causual "social" player can seriously alter the play balance. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
UPDATE: I dropped this down from an 8. This game is really tedious and repetitive. Too long for what it is. It might be because the goals are quite restrictive (you can only work on collecting 2-3 different sets of cards), which makes the trading not so dynamic. Perhaps that lack of sense of accomplisment is a valid criticism (read on).

High marks because my sister's fiance fell in love with this game despite my sister's intentions. Good strategic depth for such a light and codial trading game. Do you wait for more cards, or try to harvest as often as you can? This tension is Carcasonne-like, but it's also my only criticism I have with this game: There is no grand sense of accomplishment; after you've harvested your beans, you then start your next field; repeat until the cards run out. However, this game has trading while Carcassone has all that wasted time spent on tile-matching!

UPDATE: This is a game that I'm very close to despising because [a] everyone loves this game, which means that I play it too often!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Interesting mechanics, with hand-order and overwhelming trading element, but in general, it seems a bit chaotic and unsatisfying both strategically and entertainment-wise. The theme (cute beans) shocks me that otherwise-hardcore gamers will play this game so frequently. The theme seems to force it into a family game, in which case it is way too complicated in turn-order and bean field management for kids to play the proper game.  Now, if those limitations were eased up, I'd think it would be good for kids. Of course, then it shouldn't be as well regarded as it is, since it would strictly be a kid's game, and those notoriously do not get good rankings on BGG.  This game is kind of an anomaly when compared to other kids-themed games on the 'Geek - makes me wonder what clique of people raised this up as something more and then had everyone follow that lead.
---------
According to a few posts here, removing both the Coffee beans (24), Wax beans (22)Cocoa beans (4), and brings the deck back down to the original German version's 104 cards, and makes for a significantly shorter (20-30 minute) and arguably more appropriate, satisfying filler-like game as intended by the designer.

RATING: 7
Perhaps it was because the game was played rather loosely with the rules, but this didn't seem like a game of competition to me, more like everyone trying to help everyone else get the best score. Now, I don't mind cooperative games, like Shadows Over Camelot, or whatever, but not when it's an accidental result of a design flaw. I'd like to try this again with people who actually try to win, sometime, and see whether there's a game here or not. SECOND PLAY: with six people all trying to WIN the game, this is a MUCH better game, so I raised the rating from 5 to 7. (It's still not particularly exciting, but it's decent.)

RATING: 5.75
Beans, beans, the magical fruit, the more you plant, the more take root.  Until you have to dig up perfectly good green beans to plant an unwanted cocoa bean.  I think I prefer the cutthroat approach where players are constantly at risk of being forced to plant beans they don't want, even if someone else wants the bean.  Only when multiple players want the same beans should true trading take place.  Otherwise, the game is mostly just about randomly drawing cards and distributing them as needed until people end up with similar scores.  I've now played with 5 and 6 players; I think this would be more enjoyable with 3 or 4.

RATING: 7
A well-implemented trading game.  There is asymmetrical valuation of goods, combined with some hidden information so deal-making requires shrewdness as well as a bit of calculation.  The pressure of forced planting from your hand drives you to make deals.  Everyone stays involved the whole game, and there is a pleasant rhythm of trading, planting, harvesting. Kids absolutely love this game - rate it a 9 if you are playing with 8 - 12 year olds.

RATING: 8.2
Players: 3-7
Time: 45-90 (usually longer with more players)

Players are bean farmers, sowing beans (cards) in fields to make money. Bigger fields (more cards) means more money. Negotiating and trading for the beans you want is the core of the game. Is more fun than this description sounds.

RATING: 8
People who don't "get" Bohnanza aren't my people. That is, people who go out of their way, step on each others' toes and, abruptly and without warning, say anything and everything and beg. These *are* my people.

People who are relatively quiet and polite and enjoy themselves. These are my people too. Yep, it always works well. I never have to shun someone from my life after a game, despite harsh words and feral grudgesmirks.

There's nothing to it players, just come to the table and talk. It's easy to set expectations for any group, to establish incentives, and no one shies away from a simple deck of cards.

RATING: 9
What a great little card game. This has been increasingly one of our favorite card games to play on game night. The game has just the right amount of strategic play, interaction, and slight screwage factor to keep you interested on each card turned over. All players are involved on each turn so it's a big plus. You hand management, trading, and donating cards all makes this one fine game when all players are involved. 

I had this for years before playing, after my 1st rating of an 8, I have bumped this up to a 9 for me.

RATING: N/A
This is a very nice trading game. The game is easy to understand. In the game you try to grow and sell the best boons. You start with a number of cards where you can not change the order. That makes the game a fun challenge. You try to get the best boons. In the beginning you play cautiously but later you become a driven trader. It is a very fun game to play and definitely recommended

RATING: 6
This game is a fun little card game of collecting sets of different types of beans and harvesting for points. This is different from Uwe Rosenberg's  normal games.  The concept revolves around trading efficiently with other players but if you do not trade you will not win.

Pros: fast, can accommodate up to 7 players, fairly easy to teach and a lot of player interaction.

Cons: not really thematic

RATING: 3
I have played this 3 times and been bored or annoyed every single time.  I just can't bring my self to look deep enough into such a abstract mechanic to optimize what I'm 'planting' against what everyone else is planting.  I also do not see this as a good gateway game.  Either people are way to willing to trade or they are so miserly that it screws not only their opponent, but also their own shot at winning.  I'd rate this a 2 but I have a hard time telling my buddies I WONT play something unless it's just broken. Bleh.

RATING: 9
Abszolút értem a játék sikerét :) Mindennek az alapja, hogy rengeteg interakció van benne. Tényleg, kb., mintha a piacon lenne az ember, úgy licitálunk néha egymásra a jobbnál jobb babok beszerzéséért, vagy pont azért, hogy az ember túladjon némelyiken.
Nyilván nem szabad véresen komolyan venni. Veszélyes lehet olyan társaságokban, ahol túl erős egyes emberek kapcsolata (pl. csak egymással üzletelnek), vagy éppen ellenkezőleg (nem hajlandóak egymással koketálni).
Csak ajánlani tudom, ha a könnyed szórakozás a cél. A grafika, a babok, az elnevezések mind teli találat!
A játék zsenije persze a kezünkbe kerülő lapok fix sorrendjében rejlik.

Some people think that the game bogs down with that many, but you just need to be working the trades on other people's turns to stay involved.

RATING: 8
A clever trading game with a unique twist: cards must be played from your hand in the order they were drawn. The key is to trade away cards that you don't want to play. It's more fun the more players you have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In most trading games, "hoarding cards" can be reasonable strategy. Not so in Bohnanza! Bohnanza's unique "must plant" mechanic makes planning and trading essential, yet encourages players to help others. If you can get past the non-intuitive yet simple rules, you will enjoy a thoroughly social game!

*****

[q="jkrozel"]Yes, this one works well, once you get past the looks on their faces when you tell them it's a game about bean farming...[/q]

I think I used the following to describe the theme of the game...

"You're a small-time farmer who's big WalMart supplier could care less about your needs and gives you whatever beans they have in stock at the time. You, however, love beans and can't bear to just throw them away. But these beans are sprouting so you, or at least someone, must plant them in the order they came to you. Of course, once you've planted the beans, you're free to rip them out whenever you want."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A very good game for larger groups (5-7). Easy to learn and makes good pace with a lot of fun and just the right amount of luck involved. Highly recommend.

RATING: 7
Very simple trading that belies a lot of complexity, particularly as beans' values shift as they are sold and become unavailable. Players must constantly reassess the value of their plots, as the unchangeable order of their hand can force plans to change quickly - this also requires savvy trading in order to clear out unwanted beans.

Plus, beans!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dani

Uwe Rosenberg első igazán sikeres tervezése, még mielőtt sérvet okozó nehézségű dobozokat állított elő agrokultúra és barlangberendezés témákban!

Az egyszerű kártyapakliban kb. féltucat különböző babfajta található, eltérő számban. Ezeket gyűjtik szettekbe a játékosok úgy, hogy a kezükből lejátszák, vagy egymás között cserélgetik. Mindenki csak két féle babot termeszthet egy időben, ráadásul minden körben ki kell játszani valamit a kezünkből, így gondosan kell előre tervezni. Ha ez még nem lenne elég, a kézben tartott és felhúzott lapok sorrendje kötött, nem lehet rakosgatni őket - így egy-egy gyengébb, a portfólióba nem illő lapot addig kell "eladni" amíg a kezünkön előre nem ér!

Kiváló dizájn, amit az is jelez, hogy közepes odafigyeléssel igen szoros játékokat lehet kihozni, annak ellenére, hogy a szerencse elég komoly faktor. Mivel "csak" egy pakli kártya, igen olcsó, bármilyen táskában elfér, plusz könnyen tanulható... igazi családi és utazós telitalálat!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
My favourite gateway game, and chock full of juicy game theory. Still not sick of it even after 30-ish plays. I'm tinkering with the expansions in High Bohn Plus at the moment, and they look promising.

The core of this game is churning through n[E(x)-1] > E(x) for n players while hoping everyone else slept through high school algebra.

Update: promoted to 9 due to years of undiminished enjoyment.

Update 2014: For me this is very dependant upon the group. I'm enjoying this one better with a group that plays more for fun than taking the winning seriously. Previous plays have always been a more processional and dull affair. Now I discover that more open and fun trading with plenty of talking it up makes for a significantly better game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
People use to talk very good about this game.  Anyhow, it didn't grab my attention from reading the rules, the reviews and the different comments here on BGG.  Nevertheless, I tried a friend's copy and, against my negative expectations, it turned out to be a nice little negotiation game full of interaction.  Players are farmers that grow beans in two or three different fields.  They have to play cards in order of appearance.  The only way to modify this is to exchange cards with the other players.  The one to do the best transactions will be the winner.

RATING: 8.1
Bohnanza (Both the Rio Grande year 2000, 2-7 player, 11 bean edition, and the Rio Grande year 2007, 3-5 player, 8 bean fan edition) -- Played several times with  four-players; once with seven players.  Game seemed too long for its weight until we realized our four-player group was using the seven-player expansion included in the Rio Grande year 2000 edition.  

Tying hand management to trading is a brilliant way to ensure an interactive game.  Yes, you can manage your hand by harvesting fields early to make room for more lucrative crops (or for crops in which you are long-suited, as well), but trading not only accelerates hand management and enables more profitable fields, it makes for a more interactive, fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played once with 4P and once with 5P. Despite possessing all the persuasion skills of a mute hamster, Bohnanza is a negotiation game I can actually get behind. At the heart of this set collection game is a brutal rule barring the rearrangement of one's hand of cards, which necessitates the trading out of unwanted cards in exchange for favourable cards. 

Like any negotiation game, Bohnanza is dependent on the group you play with – you ideally need a small group who is open to trades, but won't drag the game through endless bargaining. Interestingly, it is harder to freeze out a leader under these conditions as it tends to collectively hurt the rest of the group. The unavoidable drawback is that it runs a little too long for its own good, even when trades are kept short. While this is a rather severe negative for me, I'd still go for this if I had to choose a negotiation game to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2009: 8. One of the best card games ever!  Lots of fantastic player interaction make this one a real winner across generations, genders and gaming experience. A real hit with everyone I've shared it with, a real gateway game to other stuff.  Highly recommended, although lately I've grown a little bored of it, but playing with more competitive, experienced players usually ups the ante. Deserves a spot in your collection.

Update 2014: 7. Despite my enthusiasm for the game waning a little, this is still an excellent game. I love seeing how people's personalities manifest themselves in the kinds of trades that they make; the free form trading can bring out a lot of creativity. Continues to be a great gateway game.

P:2-7
Best: 5-6

#card #6+ #trading #family #gateway #classic #light-medium

RATING: 6
In the course of five years I've tried to play this game numerous times but for the life of me I cannot make it work. Even though I love trading, negotiation and bidding games, I am unable to muster any enthusiasm for the theme of planting beans. The art is supposed to be cartoonish and fun, but for me it looks like dumb toilet humour. I've played the game with friends, random people and geeks at boardgame camps, yet every time the game is finished my only emotion is "meh...". I've tried enough and I'm done. Even though this is a top 250 game, my copy is going up for sale (I'll be lucky to get a few bucks for it).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Irritating trading game with some nice ideas.  The hand forcing you into a position where you must trade with other players is a wonderful idea, but it all feels strangely chaotic and systematic at the same time.  I've yet to play a game of this where I was with folks that enjoyed this.  For a social game, it is important for at least the majority of players to like what's going on.

RATING: 6.8
Talk fast, negotiate convincingly and be willing to quickly judge and react for if you do not, deals with be made without you and that will only serve to hinder you in this fun sort-of set collecting negotiation game. Given this, I think this game can actually fall flat with people who aren't willing to talk or negotiate at all, or people who want to take it too structurally/methodically in their negotiation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I don't like negotiation games, but I do have to make an exception for this one. This is a brilliantly frustrating card game. You're dealt a hand full of different bean cards and you're trying to collect sets of them. You only start out with two fields, meaning you can only start selecting sets of two kinds of beans. The game revolves around that players are not allowed to arrange their hand, the cards have to be played the order they're dealt. This makes it really hard to harvest a large set of the same kind of beans, since your hand is clogged with all kinds of beans. Players have to make deals to get rid of cards not in their favour. Somehow, the way you're basically forced to negotiate works for me. Another great mechanic is that when harvesting beans, cards are turned over and become money. This way the amount of beans gets lower as well, making it harder to get large sets in the future.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Bit long with the people I play with, negotions go on forever! Still a game with huge laughs and is great fun to play - but we wouldn't want to play more than one game at a time

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A really unique card game. The fact you can't change the order of the cards in your hand make you strategise and trade what blocks your way to better gameplay and a lot is dependent on how you can best utilize trading vs managing your hand. You don't want to give other players a huge boost, but on the other hand you don't really want to spoil your way to a great bean field. It's a game of balancing all that stuff. For me the relying on trading isn't something I would go for. I am not good at negotiating and I don't really like to play games that depend on it. But still this game is a pearl in its genre. Just not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Interesting hand management and set collecting card game. In this game, you cannot reorder the cards in your hand and you have to play them in that order. While it was difficult to not accidentally rearrange my hand, it created a rather unique challenge that I had not seen in another game. I also thought this was game was engaging as it really encouraged you to trade, including giving away cards. My one complaint was it did run a bit long.

RATING: 6.5
Bohnanza is a fun game, one I never mind playing but usually don't seek out myself. The time this was really popular with my friends I preferred Wizard and Dalmuti a lot.
I like the collecting part, the design of the cards is cute, the mechanism where you cannot change the order of your hand is quite unique; I dislike the hectic part where everyone makes you an offer for your cards. Oh, and it goes on a bit too long. But it is not without appeal, and as most card games it is easy to bring along.

Enjoyable game. Played/playing a few variants of this as well - Al Cabohne, in particular. Play 2 player with trading too, rather than the Bean Dual rules.

Fan edition so fan art - including one (pretty rubbish!) picture from Uwe himself. Glad he got someone else to do the art for Agricola etc....

Note to self: *Insert weak bean-based pun as closing comment at a later date*

Update March 2017 (from original 2010 comment) - upgraded from 7 to 7.5; have played a few times with Emma and have enjoyed :-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
An extreme exercise in boredom.  The main problem I have with this game is just how terrible it is with a large group of players.  I got two turns the one and only time I played this with 7 people while everyone else got three.  It's very difficult to do anything worthwhile when you barely have any ability to affect the game.

Suffers from the same problem as Settlers where you can just have a miserable time if the randomness sticks you with resources nobody else wants so they never deign to trade with you.  This isn't always an issue, but it can rear its head in some games.

Perhaps the biggest issue is that it's just so boring.  Draw cards.  If they match, keep and plant them.  If they don't, hope to God someone else wants them.  Rinse and repeat.  Sure, many games can be successful being this simple, but this game is just too dry to be of much fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Great game where sharing at the right time can increase your odds of winning.

Play tip: When teaching the game stress the importance of leaving the cards in the order that they are drawn. The game relies on random draw order to promote sharing and untimely harvesting of fields.

RATING: 6.5
A fun little filler.  I'm generally not big into trading/negotiation games, but this game plays quickly enough that it doesn't turn into too painful a process.  The cartoon artwork on the cards is fun, and the necessity of getting "runs' that was pointed out to me during the rules explanation just added to the atmosphere (particularly in context of the "beans" theme).  It's probably a good thing that the theme is light-hearted because these trading/negotiation games always have the potential to leave a bad taste in some people's mouths!  Game design: 4/5  Personal enjoyment: 2.5/5  Total: 6.5/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very good negotiation/trader filler. It's a set-collection game, but each player can only keep two in-development sets going at once with large sets worth significantly more points. The trick is that you're forced to place several cards on your turn, which very likely means you will have to prematurely score a good set in order to start another one -- unless the unwanted cards can be traded, or even donated, first.

There is effectively no downtime as all players are involved in the negotiations, but it can drag on a bit. I admire the design but can't imagine wanting to play it often -- the luck of the card draws is forgivable in a filler, but the negotiations are so one-dimensional that they rapidly become tiresome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
[3 plays] Initial reaction.  I had a good time playing this game.  I played it 3 player and 4 player.  It was pretty easy to learn and catch onto.  IMO this type of game is better than "party games" for just playing a light game and socializing.  There is some thought and planning you need to do to play it, but really the winner is probably who could negotiate the best trades.  It is a very social game because you have to wheel and deal and make trades.  Playing 4 players was better than playing 3 player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[RGG 2000 Edition] {Farming; trading, set collection: optimal 6-7p} Bohnanza is a nice family card game. It's involves many player interactions in the trading and donation. It's quite chaotic and the most efficient way to get scores to trade more frequently; players can't win if they refuse to trade due to the special hand management requirement. It seems that Bohnanza has low replayability. The fun washes away quickly after consecutive plays because every game seems to be the same. I will occasionally choose this game for new players, though.

The illustration of the cards is hilarious. The information on the cards is effective. It's an interesting idea to use the card back as a gold token. 

[expansions] The basic set is enough for casual plays. I will not buy its many expansions because I think they only make the game more chaotic without enhancing player interaction nicely. Nonetheless, Rabohnzel (not an expansion) seems to be a funny game.

[player mat] Simon Hunt's player mats are really good.  It helps players to understand the rules easily.  One should print it out and play.

RATING: N/A
Piantare semi e fare il fattore non è mai stato così divertente! In Semenza, sarete tutti dei coltivatori che piantando semi e raccogliendone i frutti dovrete cercare di ottenere il maggior profitto possibile. Quando venderete, avrete maggior guadagno se riuscirete a vendere un maggior numero di carte dello stesso tipo, ma dovrete piantare solo i semi che avrete in mano, e se non li vorrete, potrete scambiarli o donarli agli altri giocatori. Se agirete con furbizia potrete ottenere i semi che vi serviranno per avere raccolti numerosi, ma dovrete stare attenti a non aiutare troppo i vostri avversari. Al termine del gioco chi avrà ottenuto più denaro, sarà il vincitore. Semenza è un piccolo e semplice gioco di carte, divertente e veloce; adatto a tutta la famiglia, da 2 a 7 giocatori: una vera “semenza di gioco”.

Elenco elementi di gioco:
162 Carte
1 Libretto delle regole

RATING: 7
Great game, for some reason crowds of people demand to play this game long after it moves to your "second choice" pile.  Pay close attention to the instructions telling you which cards to get rid of depending on the number of players - and remember to draw 4 at the end of your turns in a 6+ player game - this will make it take 45 minutes rather than an hour or longer.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Trading properties was always my favorite part of playing Monopoly as a kid.  This game condenses that trading mechanic down to it's essence.  Trading games only work if all players are willing to trade, and this game forces you to do it.  Sometimes the trades are more beneficial to one player than another, but it's so light and quick it doesn't really matter.  I don't think I've ever won a game but I don't care, I still enjoy myself.
My spouse generally hates trading in games but she will play and enjoys Bohnanza.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Simple enough to learn for new players while having enough strategy for veterans. 

What is most fun is the mechanic where you are forced to plant the first bean in your hand. This inspires action during the trading phase. If you like trading/haggling/bartering for large groups while still being very simple to learn, this could be the game for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Engaging set-collection/trading card game. The idea is to collect enough cards in a set to be able to sell them for money (victory points). The difficulty lies in that you cannot alter the order of your hand and cards have to be played in the sequence that they were drawn. In order to manoeuvre around this obstacle players have to trade cards with one another in an attempt to add to their sets. The theme of planting beans in fields isn't the most inspiring I've ever encountered but as a trading game 'Bohnanza' works better than most as players have to trade in order to progress and this aspect of the game is controlled more by the cards rather than the personalities/relationships of the players, which is often a failing of this type of game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very clever trading game with a humorous element added in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've mostly played this with my ex girlfriend.  Fun, but for whatever reason, I just can't ever seem to win.  I think in all the times we've played, I must've won once.  That's not why we broke up (she decided to move) but I haven't really pulled it out since.  I'm considering giving it to her, since I know she gets so much more enjoyment out of it than I.

RATING: 7
gehört Alisa

RATING: 6
Played 5+ times. Bohnanza is a good trading game and a hoot to play.  I enjoy the fast and furious trading and 'donating' of beans.  There's definitely a political element to it as you can give points to people and beneficial (lopsided) trades are often made and you want to convince people that you're not winning so that you can benefit.  The length is good without the expansion.  7 players is probably too much. 2006/09/21

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun game! Even the two player variant is interesting. It will take 2 or 3 turns for beginners to understand how it works. Not being permitted to change the order of the cards in your hand is non-intuitive so you have to keep an eye out for that.

Scores are always close. You will think you are doing well and are going to win, only to find that you are the poorest of the group. 

The groups needs to be aggressive in the trade phase or the game will fail. It's the heart of the game. If everybody just try to help everybody else, it loses all of it's luster. It's a game where you have to be selfish and nasty.

On the downside, the game can be a bit long for what it is. And the game is higly dependant on the group.

Az egyetlen probléma a játékosok hozzáállása:mivel szinte mindent lehet és szabad ezért úgymond lehet "hûderendesvagyok" (értsd  ingyen odaadok egy babot pedig még egyáltalán nem szükséges hogy megváljak tôle) és "hudebunkóvagyok" formában játszani. RATING: 4
I am baffled about this game, having heard so much praise for it: the mechanics are novel, but I was not engaged. The game seems a little too long and the decisions seem marginal. I'm left wondering if I botched a rule, but there are only like five rules.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Home made
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.9
I liked Bohnanza the one time I played it, but it wasn't interesting enough that I really want to pursue it further. It's somehow simultaneously too light for how long it is, and yet too long for how heavy it is? I'm not quite sure how to say it. The core mechanic is trading, and it does it well, but it suffers from that core weakness of competitive trading games: No one will ever offer you a trade unless it also benefits them, and either you have to gamble on who it will benefit more, or someone involved is an idiot. And I hesitate to call a game strategic when the driving strategy is to trick people into helping you -- that's a bluffing game. And yet Bohnanza tries to be strategic? I don't know. There's also the third option, where you stonewall because you know that the trade can't possibly be as beneficial for you as the other guy; but then the game seems stuck? At least in Bohnanza it is enough to stonewall once; you don't have to keep up the embargo for the rest of the game, just long enough to ruin the other guy's timing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game seems to be about 50% arithmetic, 50% negotiation. Yuck.

RATING: 7
I really like Bohnanza - it's easy to get people to play because of the cute illustrations, and depending on the group you're playing it with you can play in a light manner (trading cards sometimes for "favors" to be redeemed later in the game - one group of mine even created levels from "small favor" to "favor" to "big favor" and beyond, and used them almost like commodities) to a cutthroat game where sometimes the active player has to [i]pay[/i] people to take beans he does not want, in order to avoid digging up a field.  Fun.

Updated January 2010 - Reduced from an 8 to a 7.  Not a big change, but the ratings are to an extent based on how much one wants to play a given game, and while I do still play Bohnanza, when I see it on the shelf it does not call to me like it once did.

RATING: 7
This one didn't do it for me at first.  

It was neglected on my shelf for the longest time.  Rediscovering Bohnanza was a great treat, because I liked it a lot better the second time around.  

I think the difference was in who I was playing with.  My first Bohnanza experiences were with my inlaws, who play games very kindly and with a certain amount of co-operation.  They try to ensure that everyone is enjoying themselves.  
The rediscovery happened with a much more cut-throat group, which makes the game infinitely more fun!

RATING: 7

I can tell he gets the whole concept of wheeling and dealing so he can get certain cards to get the right amount to get the coins he wants.  I lost this game, and while I blame everyone for instantly just drawing and than blurting out "Hey I got one for you and these other two you would like" - Her Father quickly pointed out in a witty manner, that for the same reasons, is the reason I lost.  I couldn't apply burn medication fast enough for that one.

Still lots of fun.

RATING: 7.3
A classic game that we've owned for years, and used to play extensively many years back, but which now only sees the table occasionally. Bizarrely we've only just discovered that we've been playing it wrong all these years. Our "house rules" meant that all the power was with the seller, as he was not forced to plant the two face-up cards he draws. Now we've started playing it according to the real rules that gives the game a whole new dynamic. I think I prefer the proper version better, though our version made for a pretty enjoyable variant, especially considering that we "invented" it entirely by accident.

RATING: 8
A worthwhile game to buy, because it creates lots of interaction at the table, which imho cannot be easily replaced by online play. Enjoyed the grudges and time-limited offers that bring laughs to the table. This is a game where it is more fun to mess with the others and gang up against the leader than it is to win. It is however a little difficult to teach to the impatient, as there are lots of rules, especially the one where you cannot rearrange your cards. A 4-5 player game could take hours if the players are first-timers.

RATING: 4.5

The subsequent times had enough edge to the dealmaking that made a successful swap feel more of a triumph. Still, while I recognize the cleverness of the game mechanic, the lightness of the game just doesn't add enough weight to negotiations to give me the "kick" I am looking for in a game of haggling. In short, it's hard to haggle over something you don't care that much about.

RATING: 10
2 - 7

One of my oldest favorites.

The strict rule of not reordering the cards in your hand adds spice. This produces a wonderful negotiation game, as it is sometimes preferable to give things away for free, or to trade at an unfavorable exchange rate. This makes it seem cooperative, but only one person can be the winner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Brendan's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love this game, it is fast and fairly simple, yet entertaining and highly replayable. 
In Bohnanza you start with two spots (fields) and a hand of cards that you have to play in order. You can plant a type of bean (suit) in each field, but once you plant it you are stuck with that kind, and if you want to change crops you need to score the ones you have (the more you have the more points you score), so you stop the progression and restart. It encourages interaction (trade) with other players, to get the cards you are investing in while they get theirs, etc. Also some cards are rarer than others (the rarer give a lot more points). I absolutely recommend it, but it needs at least 3 players to make it good, I would say.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Inside Big Book of Madness
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Yes it's silly. Very silly. But if you can't master many of the demands of Bohnanza, you're dead meat as a gamer. 

Can't bid? Can't negotiate? Can't suck people in? Can't Co-operate? Whoa, you're in trouble. 

The Bean Game is an excellent place to learn these skills and a lovely kind place to learn them, if you're new. Until some fucker comes along and decides to score the game. Bastard. 

But it's still a massive bundle of German fun, and I love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Most of my plays have been friendly affairs with new players.  I am looking forward to playing this with a group of cutthroat traders - but will that come down to the luck of the draw?  This can be a fun lightweight game with newbies, but can it cross over to something better?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

My daughter especially likes playing Bohnanza with the fan edition.  Quite a lot of clever artwork from professionals and fans alike.  May make the game a bit rough for beginners (although the cards do all have the standard card icons in the corners), fans of the game will enjoy the unique artwork on each card.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great gateway card game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Gameplay is hair brained. I find it incredibly difficult to change from the current trade and the macroscopic trends of the game.

The game is cleverly made. The art is ugly but grows on you. The rulesheet makes my eyes bleed. The game deserves praise but I do not often crave the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I never would have bought this game based on the description. Bean farming? Really? We played at a friend's house. This game was chosen because we had a time constraint and I wanted something I hadn't already played. We loved it. I bought a copy for the family and the 3 of us play regularly (we show cards when our daughter plays and sometimes argue over which of us is taking advantage of her in trades but it's otherwise fun). I've since played this with some non-gamer friends who also loved it. Simple, elegant, accessible and yet there is strategy in watching card counts and lining up your hand to play into available farms. It's not high strategy, but there is enough to make it engaging for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I just really love this game. I spend the whole game repeating, "It's all about the beanconomy". If you get excited about trading and coercing your friends then this is the game for you. The main goal is to trade favors, I give you a bean you give me a bean.
The art is not that great, but it grows on you so now I adore it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
(NH)
Letter Grade: B+.  Accessible, teachable, fun, and great throughout its player range.  Delightful mix of simply-deployed mechanics.  Just ever-so-slightly long, and theme tends to turn off adults if you give them a chance to think about it. 

Always goes over well, once people realize the theme isn't childish, though I find it oddly difficult to teach.  I really love the flow of this game.  It scales extremely well, all the way down to 2.  This has been my go-to gateway cardgame, and as I end up introducing lots of people to games Bohnanza hits the table a lot.  

[05-08-09]: Old rating: 8.5.  New rating: 7.5.  I love Bohnanza but am just now coming out on the other side of a burnout with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a fun relatively quick trading game.  Figuring out how to get beneficial trades, while not being so tight-fisted as to lose the trades you need to get rid of beans you don't want is an interesting line to try to walk.  If you trade too freely, you lose out on the cards you need to the other people that inevitably also need them.  If you are too stingy, you end up getting flooded with cards you don't want and can't ever build up a decent field.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The game [i]claims[/i] to be a sweet fun bean-trading game.  In reality, it is a bitter and lurid affair of intrigue, backstabbing, and politics.

RATING: 5
Decent unique card game that plays differently as number of players change.

The game plays fast, flows well and is quite interactive. The artwork is also nice and the game doesn't outstay its welcome.

The rules are a bit difficult to get to, but after a few plays and a few mistakes they connect. The game plays poorly with more than two players imo, as it becomes an uneasy combination of luck of the draw and kingmaking.

Overall I found this game enjoyable with 2p, but I cannot reccomend it with 3p+.

Rating: 2p/6, 3p+/4

RATING: 9
Solid bartering game. Simple rules. Relatively deep strategy. Cute art and theme (it's really hard not to say "bean" in every sentence while playing). 

The setup listed in the rules results in a pretty long game. If you are in the mood for that, go for it! Otherwise, we found that removing the wax beans helps out a lot with game length. 

Both the gamers and non-gamers in our group really enjoyed this game.

RATING: 5.5
The family liked this. But I have come to feel that
1. the lack of long-term strategy makes the game a little uninteresting
2. it doesn't seem like you have that much choice in your trades. Usually you can or can't accept a given deal and there's not much room for haggling.

...Maybe what I mean by the latter is that the range of possible transactions is too coarse. When two players have a discussion, they usually just discover whether or not there's one deal they can both take. Not much haggling.

...I need to revisit this game and these comments as I actually dislike a lot of haggling. Rating might improve.

...Well no. Played it again. If you play nice it feels more like an activity than a game, just moving all the cards around to the people that want them. If you play for real it means trying to deviate from the "best" outcome by trying to get something more. But usually others can't accept any other deals, as I wrote originally. So my issue with the game is that it's a game of haggling which doesn't have much room to haggle.

Also, the 3p game seems incredibly loose, with players frequently attaining the maximum payout for a card type.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[Rated 2005/05/06, based on 1 play]

The artworks keeps this light-hearted, even if the negotiation should be cut-throat.  Being forced to play cards in order makes this quite focussed on making the most of what you've got on the turn you get it, rather than strategising too far ahead.

We played this wrong in missing the rule that you can't harvest a field with a single bean in unless that's the *only* thing you can do - I'm interested to see how much difference getting this right makes.  I know I made a couple of 'plant and harvest' sacrifice moves just to get a difficult bean out of the way.

RATING: 8
A very unique game by Uwe Rosenberg. I have played nothing quite like this game (until Oltre Mare, which has a similar mechanic involved). It has a very light-hearted vibe, and yet great decision making. The best aspect of Bohnanza is the negotiation and trading. It accomplishes this mechanic so well. Everyone ends up having fun through interaction. You find yourself helping other players to help yourself. Better with more players. Completely worth the price.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a weirdly charming card game with some interesting and unique mechanics.  Trade negotiations are the meat of the game, and it is impressive that such a small game is able to implement this mechanic so well.  By far the most unique card game in my collection, and I'd recommend it.  The two-player variant is rubbish though, not worth the time.

RATING: 9.5
The beauty of Bohnanza is just how simple a game it is, but so wildly entertaining, thematic, and strategic as well. There is no person who we have taught it to who has not gone on to sing its praises to their friends, and then their friends... Perfect for groups because it scales well and has an off-the-board trading dynamic, bean farming has never been so fun. From the maker of Agricola comes a less intense, charmer of a game. Another excellent introductory game for newbies.

RATING: 5.5
This game is another one that is very dependent on the crowd. With some friends, it is a wheeling-and-dealing game with people trading for futures (e.g., I'll give you this trade now, but I expect you to give be a black-eyed or better when I ask.) 

With another group, most people are trading to help each other out.

In the first instance, the game gets up to a 7 - in the latter instance, it gets down to a 4. So I'll average it at 5.5..

-Gateway game
-Deeper than it looks
-A lot of interaction
-Fun art

Bad:
-Can be ruined by a player too willing to trade
-Experienced players can exploit new players in trades
-Always feels the game lasts a little too long
-Never buy a third field

Overall:
One of the better trading games out there.  A great mix of depth and game length; however, this is best used a filler between game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An excellent trading and negotiation game with such a silly theme and excellent art that it's even more fun than the mechanics imply. Like many lightweight negotiation games, it's probably best not to take it [i]too[/i] seriously, but there's still enough meat to it to make a gamer happy. While it includes rules from 2-7p, I wouldn't play it with less than 4, as there's just not enough competition for the trades. More is better and rowdier. The game moves quickly and keeps everyone involved all the time, which is a real plus for a game that plays up to 7.

What unfortunately kills this as a real intro game is the sequence of play. Even though the game is very simple at heart, something about the sequencing is very unintuitive for non-gamers. I've taught it to about 10 non-gamers (adults and teenagers) so far - all of them had a very hard time getting comfortable with the flow of the game. Those that stuck with it eventually had a great time, but several gave up after feeling confused and frustrated for 10-15 minutes. Use this one as a fast, light game for semi-gamers, not for a quick after-dinner game to play with non-gaming acquaintances.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I am not much for card games but I am liking these new ones more and more.  I really enjoy playing this with my family as it is a game they actually understand and become competitive at.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Don't let the suggested age range on this game fool you.  My 8 year-old son absolutely LOVES this game and is always asking to play it.  It's a great deal of fun.

You plant bean fields (make melds out of matching cards for you card players out there).  The twist is that you HAVE to play the first card in your hand at the beginning of your turn.  During your turn you get a couple more cards that you have to PLAY unless you can donate them to other players.  Additionally, the order of your hand is very important so you might want to donate cards to other players to get to the cards that will help you.

It's fun and has just enough depth to keep you interested.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Love this game. Lots of interaction.

RATING: 9
This a popular game with my regular gaming group. It plays up to seven people, and can be played in about an hour so it often gets pulled out at the end of the evening.  I've been playing this game for years, and despite the fact that I don't win consistently, I always have a good time.  Any game that provides this many years of gaming fun is O.K. in my book.

One caveat: Spite can be a non-trivial factor in this game.  If that's a problem for you, then maybe Bohnanza isn't going to be your cup of tea.

RATING: 7.5
Negotiate, trade and plant beans, harvest your fields, and make money. Sounds mundane but far from it: the "bean game" is a high interactive and really fun card game. Has a unique mechanic in which players are not allowed to rearrange the cards in their hands, which forces intelligent hand management and promotes trading or other tactical choices. "Gateway" in terms of difficulty level.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I love the theme, and at first found it great - very light-hearted, lots of joking and plenty of scope for Blackadder quotes ("Some beans and some beans is four").  But it gets old very quickly, the lack of strategy begins to grate, and very quickly it plays itself as it becomes automatic to trade the drawn beans and then give away any at the front of your hand that you don't want.  These days it generates more yawns than laughs and hardly ever gets a whirl.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I loved my first try at bean trading, and thought the game (played with 3) was an easy 8. But we didn't have time to finish. 2nd try was a fun and full game with 5, and my rating struggled to hold a 7.5. After a 3rd play, with 6 this drops to 6. And I can see it dropping more with a few more plays. Some complaints: the more people you add, the more downtime and chaos. With three rounds at 6 (even 5) it really drags. There is also a monotony to the trade rhythm as well and sadly I think this is a criticism that will hold true at the more reasonable 3 or 4 player size games. "Build, trade, rip up feilds, build." Lather, rinse, repeat. The tension and excitement I felt in the first play I think was greatly heightened by the puzle of trying to get into the headspace of not rearranging cards. Once the novelty of that genuinely novel concept grows old, the game starts to feel a little stale. I'd still play this again with the right (3 or 4 person) crowd. The theme can make for some boisterous times. But in the end, it lasts a little too long and gives a little too little.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Several members of my game group believe that this game descended in a pillar of light from on high.  I don't hold that level of regard for it, but it is excellent.  One of my most successful games for nongamers.  The game is just a little too subject to the whims of fate for my tastes, and there's a significant first-player bias, and I definitely prefer other trading games, but when it comes down to it, it's still fresh after 40+ plays.  That is an incredibly high threshold.

Don't bother with the two-player rules, and stay far, far away from the fan edition.  Not only is much of the art extremely amateurish, but some of the illustrations are decidedly racist.  As long as you stick with the standard set, though, this game is a great choice.

RATING: 3
Have played two 6 player games of this, and it's just been brutal. What should be a short filler turns into a 90 minute-two hour bore. And that's with calling the game off early, we've yet to get through the deck 3 times as the rules state. It just takes way too long to cumulatively offer up and evaluate a couple dozen offers each turn.

The only thing saving this game from the trade pile is that we can play the 2 player Al Cabohne rules with this deck. My wife and I really like the way the cards can come out of the discard pile in Al Cabohne, and it's a fast hand management game, as opposed to the insufferable negotiating game the "normal" game is. 

Ended up just buying a real Al Cabohne deck, and trading this dog off.

RATING: 7
Uwe Rosenberg első igazán sikeres tervezése, még mielőtt sérvet okozó nehézségű dobozokat állított elő agrokultúra és barlangberendezés témákban!

Az egyszerű kártyapakliban kb. féltucat különböző babfajta található, eltérő számban. Ezeket gyűjtik szettekbe a játékosok úgy, hogy a kezükből lejátszák, vagy egymás között cserélgetik. Mindenki csak két féle babot termeszthet egy időben, ráadásul minden körben ki kell játszani valamit a kezünkből, így gondosan kell előre tervezni. Ha ez még nem lenne elég, a kézben tartott és felhúzott lapok sorrendje kötött, nem lehet rakosgatni őket - így egy-egy gyengébb, a portfólióba nem illő lapot addig kell "eladni" amíg a kezünkön előre nem ér!

Kiváló dizájn, amit az is jelez, hogy közepes odafigyeléssel igen szoros játékokat lehet kihozni, annak ellenére, hogy a szerencse elég komoly faktor. Mivel "csak" egy pakli kártya, igen olcsó, bármilyen táskában elfér, plusz könnyen tanulható... igazi családi és utazós telitalálat!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
7p
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like the negotiation aspect of the game, and how it ties in with the way that you may never reorder your hand.  There's a certain tactical strategy in knowing when to trade to reorder the cards in your hand, and when to hang on to what you have, but it's a unique mechanism that draws in a lot of non-gamers.  It's certainly a revolutionary design.

3 plays: 4 players
2 plays: 5 players
1 play: 5 players (Fan Edition)
2 plays: 6 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.9
Ποτέ καλιεργόντας φασόλια δεν θα πέρναγες τόσο ευχάριστα.
Παιχνίδι για 2-8 παίχτες.
''Μπές'' στο παζάρι για να εποφελείσου από τους άλλους,κοίτα να τους είσαι απαρέτητος και πρόσεχε μην τους βοηθάς άσκοπα.
Μάζεψε τα περισσότερα νομίσματα και κέρδισε.
Τα καλά deals είναι το ''κλειδί'' για την νίκη,παίξε διπλωματικά και σκόρπισε την ίντριγκα στους υπόλοιπους για να επωφεληθείς. 
Στους πολλούς παίχτες αν δεν ενδιαφέρεσαι για τα παζάρια μπορεί να βαρεθείς μέχρι να έρθει η σειρά σου.

RATING: 7
The art is great, and the game is decent. An issue I have with it is that the best way you can get an edge in this game is to memorize the cards that have already come out. I also find the bargaining ("ok, but you owe me!") kind of lame, since it makes me feel sort of slimy to truly play to win. Still, there is something enjoyable about harvesting a massive stack of beans.

RATING: N/A
Have German and English versions of Fan edition and Original German and English versions of Bohnanza and Limited Edition Tin (German version).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bohnanza reminds me of Carcassonne. On the surface it seems simple and non-confrontational, but a few plays reveal that the game contains quite a bit of meaness. It takes a little while to get accustomed to your hand of cards having a fixed order before they enter play, but this clever mechanic really drives the negotiation aspect of the game. I also like how the scored cards become the game's currency and are effectively taken out of circulation. It really mucks with the set collecting aspect of the game, which in turn keeps everyone on their toes...In short, There is a heck of lot more game here than I ever would have expected!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
2 - [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/7p/user/Vroenis]7 players[/url].
Teaching: 45 - 60 minutes.
Mastery: 40 - 50 minutes.
2p box (slightly taller).
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geektag.php?tags=embassy_%26_outpost&username=Vroenis&action=usertags]Embassy_&_Outpost[/url]

[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/outpost_mobile/user/Vroenis]Outpost mobile[/url].

[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/set_collection/user/Vroenis]Set collection[/url].
Negotiation.
Light-medium weight (2, fixed hand/card-order, negotiation).
Medium level player interaction.
Low theme application.

One of the few games that pushes past 6 players, it's good for large groups. The trading and bidding readily generates humour with the right people as they'll escalate the process and inflate value, while others will throw in commentary and try to manipulate the determination of trades. I've found that some introverts can be overwhelmed when extroverts go hard at it (we can be a loud bunch!) so it's probably worth guiding rowdy folks a bit to allow everyone a bit of time to breathe early on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A little bit of planning, a small amount of memory and playing the odds make this quite enjoyable that and the hand management aspect :)
