=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.3
A trading/negotiation game that I'd like to try again with ~5 people and correct rules :)

Players must plant a bean on their turn and then deal with two random beans that come up. With seven people, the deals are quick and chaotic, and trades are almost always 1 for 1. In reality, deals should be more complex, taking into account the frequency of certain cards.

The game seems to depend on the group you play it with. I wouldn't mind trying it again.

RATING: 8
My wife's absolute favorite game, so we play this every time she's at the table—and she easily wins more than half the time because she gives away cards left and right, then receives donations in kind later that rack up her score. (I think my record is 3-37.)

A great game for those new to Eurogaming—if someone can lead them through the first round, after which everything becomes much clearer. Don't be too hard-nosed with your deals, or else you'll be cut off and wither on the vine.

RATING: 7
Very simple and fun with a fair amount of depth.  Allison can't get enough of it whereas I'm about ready to move on.

---

Update (8-11-08):

My last two games of this have really demonstrated the experience disparity that this game can produce.  In the first, everyone was wheeling, dealing, whining, and pontificating.  People were generally accommodating, but also weren't afraid to screw each other over.  The game was an absolute blast.  I would give this game an 8 or 9.

In the second, the game devolved into simply "who needs this? here you go." Cards were frequently given and accepted, with only promises of "future considerations" given in return.  Not one time was somebody forced to plant a bean they didn't want to.  Creative trades were eschewed in favor of you-scratch-my-back-I'll-scratch-yours play.  The game was random and very dull.  I would give this game a 2 or 3 (though others still seemed to like it more).

Which game will show up next game night?

RATING: 7

Hilarious to play around non-gamers; they hear complex arguments/discussion about taking stinky beans and wax beans, and they really don't know what to think.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The trading aspect is more, as my BF pointed out, telling people what you want or want to get rid of and then hoping they have a similar situation. It's not true trading in the sense of determining values and making a deal so much as just a simple exchange of cards. That being said, I am okay with that mechanic. I think this game plays well with five or more players, for some reason. I really like the theme, it's cute, and I like the collection aspect of the game (I usually like collecting games, it's the OCD in me). It is very hard to collect enough to make it worth your while so this is a challenging game, despite its simplicity. The fact that you only play from one part of your hand is really cool and that's what makes the game so hard/fun. I like that mechanic. I generally had a lot of fun with this game and would definitely play it again. I wish I had more to say about the game but I can't think of what.

RATING: 8

RATING: 3

I can recognize that this is a fun game for people who like trading, and the twist that you can't rearrange the order of cards in your hand is an interesting one.  But it's not for me.

RATING: 8
Een spel dat vooral een handelsspel is, met lekker veel interactie.

Spelers gaan bonen verbouwen op hun velden. Verschillende bonen hebben allemaal verschillende waarden. Echter, iedereen heeft maar beperkte ruimte om bonen te planten en dus kan een speler niet al zijn bonen planten. Hij doet er goed aan om mensen te vinden die deze bonen wel graag willen hebben en misschien ook nog wel bonen heeft die jij graag wil hebben.

Deze urgentie wordt vooral verhoogt door het feit dat je verplicht bent altijd je voorste boon te planten, ook al heb je deze boon helemaal niet op je velden liggen.

Mij krijg je eigenlijk altijd wel warm voor dit spel.

RATING: 4
For me, any game that relies on a significant amount of trading automatically loses its "game" categorization and gets shifted into an "activity" category.  Invariably, someone either likes someone else more than you, isn't hip to how best to negotiate equal value trades, or doesn't pay attention to what others are collecting and ends up handing another player a win.

Yes, I am overly focused on competition and winning.  I know.

RATING: 8
I find this to be a pretty great gateway game.  It is very simple to learn & to teach.  The hardest part is remembering to not sort your cards.  It's got a very lighthearted theme.  It is light, but with lots of player interaction, making it very social.  The best part is that it sounds a little weird and complex.  So when you say "Trust me it's easier than it sounds"  And it turns out to be true, people are more willing to trust you with the next game.

Quotes Overheard from Bohnanza Pros

"If you gift me a Blue Bean now, I will surely gift you a Chili Bean later."

"Light diffraction is making my coin stack look larger than it really is. It's okay to trade with me!"

"Should I buy a third bean field? I dunno, CAN I buy a third bean field?"

"You gifted me a Coffee Bean because it ruins your setup, and I just drew Stink Bean and Wax Bean, both of which I need. PRO SKILL."

"What is that? A Garden Bean? That thing looks crazy! If I take this bean he will murder me while I sleep!"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
It's an addictive, fun, and quite strategic game with 4-5 players. First-timers will need a few rounds to get used to a few singular game mechanics, but a nice introductory trading/negotiation game with limited "screw your neighbor" moments. [UPDATE 2/28/06] Rating dropped from 8 to 6.5. Drags on a bit with more people, and the illusion that mutually beneficial trades are equal is hard to overcome. Also, once you find yourself behind, it can be incredibly difficult to get back into the game as you have to constantly add value to other players to earn points yourself, effectively making null moves or marginal increments on most turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I really like trading games and this was no exception.  While I find it kind of hard to explain to new players it gets rolling very quickly once you start playing.  Trying to properly arrange your hand and keep track of the amount of beans left to plant is pleasantly, lightly thinky and the trading tends to be friendlier than in other trading games I've tried. Good fun!

I've even found I enjoy the poorly regarded 2 player version.  Its not like playing regular Bohnanza but its still an enjoyable little filler for me and my wife.

RATING: 8
Once upon a time when I took Bohnanza everywhere...those times I didn't have any other game. One of the first games I bought, played and loved. I played in the beach, at the restaurant, christmas, the train or while camping. It is an accesible game, I love the negotiation discussions and jokes around the game. It is easy to teach and fast to finish. Wonderful with 4 players. I don't give it a 10 because there is not really a deep strategy so it becomes a little repetitive when played too much in a row. I mean, there is little variability in each play. What makes it variable are the conversations and the group. It is really boring with mid-hard eurogamers brain-burners.
